Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6W-CCH1-JDPT-T0D1-00000-00DAVID KIRKPATRICK, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND FOUNDER OF TECHONOMY MEDIA IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE.2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:57ZLexisNexisDAVID KIRKPATRICK, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND FOUNDER OF TECHONOMY MEDIA IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE.

September 6, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND FOUNDER OF TECHONOMY MEDIA

FOX: Our next guest is David Kirkpatrick. He is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect" and we want to find out what the congressional effect of yesterday's testimony of Chief Operating Officer, Sheryl Sandberg for Facebook as well as Jack Dorsey the Chief Executive of Twitter may have had on investor's appetite for both of these companies.

David, what did you make of their presentation before Congress and what do you think investor ought to take away?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, thanks Pimm. I wasn't -- well, you know, it's a different thing for each company. And I think that Jack Dorsey and Sheryl Sandberg take a quite different view of the whole thing. I think the company has came out of it well, in the sense I would call the more or less on this case and that's partly because with Google not showing up a lot of heat was taken off them and put on Google simply for its failure to show.

I also think they were more or less stared the toughest question that might have hope they would asked.

FOX: Such as?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, you know, why did this happen? And why is -- you know, considering that the New York Times had published an article today before, which unfortunately hadn't gone in the print paper that I'm aware of about Libya and how warlords are using it to target each other and selling on is what Facebook et cetera. You know, it just gives us the show how absolutely unprepared they continue to be for the scale of abuse to their platform.

And you know, you have to ask if it's happening there, what's still happening here that we just don't know about yet. The problem with this platform is they're so abusable that there are essentially infinite ways to gain their system and they have enormous distribution power. And therefore they become weaponized and they're trying desperately to deal with that and I do admire and respect many of the gestures they're taking and the people they've hired to try to step up to the problem but they have not yet fully step up to the problem. And I think it's very different from Twitter than for Facebook though.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, it's interesting you talked about how unprepared they are for this. I was sort of shocked that they weren't grilled more on this subject of the actual panel which was the security issue and foreign agents using their platforms. So there's a lack of scrutiny over the topic of the actual hearing suggest to you that there's going to be zero asking from a congressional standpoint on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Probably you're right about that. I would say that's very good speculation. You know, theoretically what we really were expecting was keep probing about Russian manipulation in particular and what is being put in place to prevent it from harming the election this fall.

We didn't really hear that in any great detail. We heard a lot of -- in my opinion fairly rode statements that have the same thing that have been said in public before by Sheryl Sandberg. And I think Jack Dorsey more candidly and with a more humility acknowledge the Twitter really isn't yet doing enough and to some extent doesn't even know what to do.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: The different thing, the two companies in my opinion, is that Facebook desperately wants to convey the notion that they have this in hand. Jack doesn't have that arrogance. He also doesn't have the money to even make that claim because Twitter is so much less profitable and so much smart. But you know, in Mark Zuckerberg with Kara Swisher month or so ago, he actually said the problem would be solved by the end of 2019 with artificial intelligence.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Go back and check it out. I mean, that just totally wrong and really naive and dangerous. Sheryl didn't say that exactly yesterday but she really less -- you know, this thing it's on us that we want to prepare to be as a very back candid way of accepting responsibility.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: He doesn't really say, oh my gosh, we are ashamed that we built the platform that did not have sufficient controls and protections against abuse. We are desperately trying to fix it. We don't fully know how we need your help government outside civil society, please help us, that what they should be saying.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I'm really glad you said that, David, because -- I think I don't know about Pimm, but I know that when I was listening to the testimony I found Jack Dorsey to be a lot more humble and thoughtful about his answers and I thought Sheryl Sandberg was very practiced and very polished but it felt like she was reading the script that she had been giving or she drafted ahead of time. And I feel like David, you're kind of reiterating that feeling even though when we talked with the people yesterday they thought that Sheryl Sandberg had done the better job and certainly that seems to be what the stock action reflected. What's your view on that?

KIRKPATRICK: You just restated exactly what I believe. I think Sheryl is a very-scripted, relatively insincere public speaker particularly at this point. I think much of the problem that happen on Facebook that have lead to this manipulation and abuse of Facebook in the United States and Germany, in Brexit and so many other instances really are a consequence of the failure to build controls into the advertising system that she over saw.

Therefore she is personally responsible for many of the thing that went wrong. And she essentially escaping any kind of real accounting for that and nobody -- because that's unfortunately even though some have said yesterday Senate question showed more intelligence and I thought Senator Warner actually on Bloomberg bragging about how he thought that this committee has smarter questions than the hearing when Zuckerberg was testifying. I really don't think that on balance the senators really understand how the stuff all works and who is responsible. And, you know, what any of the mechanics are inside the company. And that's partly because Facebook has been consummately un-transparent. I mean, they really do not show any real humility, zero. And that is a big difference with Jack Dorsey.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick --

KIRKPATRICK: They don't know what they're doing.

FOX: OK. Look into the future and we're going to continue the conversation. I just want you to look into the future for us, maybe 5, maybe even a decade from now. Do you believe that there will be government regulations that in some way affect social media technology?

KIRKPATRICK: 100%. I would say it's a lot less than 10 years. We're talking about two-year probably and it will be very fragmented global regulatory environment that they're going to be getting regulation all over the place where we're seeing that in Europe quite dramatically. It's happening. It will happen here, totally.

FOX: And maybe investors are already picking up on that because I just looking at the trading in Facebook shares, they are down now heading for the fifth consecutive trading session of losses, Facebook shares are now lower on the year, they are down about six percent.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes. We're going to continue conversation with David Kirkpatrick. So stay where you are, because we can talk about Facebook. Facebook is actually the one laggard among all of them that is down on the air. People talk about the same rally and how that's really driven stock market. Well, certainly Facebook has been entirely left out of that and sort of interesting to see in question whether it's the sort of lack of stability that David Kirkpatrick was talking about that perhaps lead into that.

FOX: Well compare to the performance of Twitter and not to say that the stock performance is a proxy for whether the companies are going to be regulator or not but Twitter shares they're up more than 30% this year, compare that to Facebook, the shares as I said they are down about six in quarter percent so far this year.

We've got much more with David Kirkpatrick of Techonomy and also the author of the "Facebook Effect" talking about what happens when government regulator make it very interested in your business.

(BREAK)

FOX: Our guest is David Kirkpatrick, he is the founder and the chief executive of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect."

David, I'm going to have you put three Ph.D. dissertations into a very short amount of time. I want to get your thoughts on robotics artificial intelligence and machine learning. Are these are just buzz words or are we going to have to learn more details about the companies that create this kind of technology?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, those are huge, huge issues that are all deeply connected. Certainly, machine learning is a significant subset of artificial intelligence and robotics is increasingly control by artificial intelligence.

We are going to see these technologies and particularly A.I. in general become a more and more central part of how systems work around everything we do in our personal lives, in our work lives, in industrial circumstances in government, everywhere it's just the direction that technology is heading including even in the area we were discussing for social media where it's -- you know A.I. is said to be the technology that will solve the problem by some practitioners. So yes, it's huge. These are the technologies to watch.

ABRAMOWICZ: So what's the company -- which companies are the ones to watch who are best sort of adopting machine learning and artificial intelligence to practical applications and will be a commercial success who haven't already been recognize?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, the interesting thing about that is it's not a surprising answer. There are a lot of small companies that are doing very innovative thing in terms of the actual software but the key with A.I. to make it successful is that scale of the dataset that you have to work with which then you use to train "machine learning" which takes, you know, continued passes over a decision making process with more and more and more data and gets better and better.

So therefore the people who have the most data who are also working on A.I. are the ones who will win and that basically limited to a very small group, which is Amazon, Facebook, Google, Microsoft to a lesser extend, Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu, you know, there are companies that have a very good -- their main expertise in certain fields like Uber and self-driving and, you know, delivery of humans and other things but in general I would say the companies that are going to win on A.I. are Amazon, Facebook and Google must of all.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, full disclosure I have the pressure of attending one of your Techonomy sessions and I learned that companies such as SAPOracle, those people that are in the background of all of these databases particularly for industrial applications they are also making Artificial Intelligence in the mining of data a key stone of their strategy to help their costumers. Can you elaborate on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, certainly and SAP is an example of a very large company that also has access to an awful lot of data and they're working really hard with A.I. So it's not to say they aren't doing smart stuff. It's similarly salesforce.com, Oracle as you mentioned, IBM is of course a company who is watching product for several years, kind of leading their charge of image management and they are talking more about A.I. and lesson about watching now but certainly IBM believes A.I. is key to a future.

You know, I wouldn't think it's over stating it to say every technology company and consumer or enterprise oriented software and services recognizes that A.I. is probably the central technology that will determine whether they win or not. It's how well do you deploy A.I. and A.I. solutions, whether you're building yourself or you are buying it and deploying it that was built by others.

One of the things that I think we probably will see going back to what I said before about Amazon and other is that especially we get AmazonGoogle and Microsoft all offer their own cloud hosting services, they will be able to offer A.I. services as part of their cloud services to enterprise customers and start aps and that is going to be a key differentiator that they will use to try to compete with one another. And again, Amazon, being the largest has the biggest advantage thought.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I have to wonder as you talk, David, as you were saying earlier about the big tech giants winning just simply due to the scope of the data that they have. Will this scrunch (ph) to innovation? In other words, without democratization of that data and of that power, that ability to try to come up with the best algorithms and the best machine learning processes, are we going not get necessarily the best ideas?

KIRKPATRICK: No, in a sense it's the scale of these companies to begin with that is at risk of scrunching innovation or concentrating it unfairly. I think that -- this is I believe and I think goes to the hearing yesterday and why it was somewhat disappointed (ph) them.

The few scale of Facebook, Google and Amazon in particular is such a new development in society and so overwhelming the important from so many aspects because there's -- the power they have to control economics activity to gain insight into social and societal and even governmental function to develop A.I. So the A.I. piece is just one part of that but yes, this companies had an unfair advantage because of the scale and, you know, it's one the reason why Jeff Bezos is the richest man in the world, worth of $160 -- $170 billion, the market has recognize that.

But it's very intertwined set of issues that have super complicated. It is a big topic for us to Techonomy and I'm glad that Pimm mentioned what we're doing here because we really think that the Techonomy host conference and publishes stuff on our website, Techonomy.com, et cetera.

This whole issue of A.I. has impacted influence in long-term implications and this is simultaneous of the scale of the small number of companies. These are some of the biggest strategic questions that not only business but society has rustled with.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, to get a little bit more in the weeds because Amazon and the Amazon factor always in the background when it comes to any kind of commercial enterprise now whether it's web services, you described or retail and indeed even the healthcare initiative, what do you believe will be the next industry to be disrupted by Amazon?

KIRKPATRICK: One that I would be pretty seriously expecting is banking. They've got -- and I would say, probably they've got their eyes on insurance as well. I mean, the healthcare thing is still very nascent but they did hire a very immanent healthcare writer and research doctor to work them and at JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway on a kind of overall sort of employee oriented project to begin with --

FOX: Right. But do you think insurance and banking, the finance industry?

KIRKPATRICK: Oh, yeah. I mean, look, think of how much banking inspiration Amazon must already had given the scale of commerce that is being concentrated through its platform. You know, it's getting enormous influence. I mean, certainly it offers credit card services are at various sorts and partnership with others now.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: And that's just the beginning. You know, the economy is going digital. So the digital dominant companies are going to have an advantage in almost every industry.

ABRAMOWICZ: But don't think want to avoid the regulation, the oversight that comes along with paying a bank?

KIRKPATRICK: Maybe. Maybe not. I mean, I think Amazon and Jeff Bezos is -- this is one thing he does share with Elon Musk is fearlessness and a willingness to confront unexpected, you know, obstacles and just sort of power through. I don't think that a fear of banking regulation would stop Amazon what the insight that they really wanted to get into that.

I think what would stop and potentially is the fear of antitrust or some kind of new regulatory oversight that they're disparate to avoid but again, the conventional antitrust doesn't even really apply because Amazon tacticals (ph) are in so many industry simultaneously that they're gaining additional scale without actually dominating anyone industry.

I mean, they do dominate online retails so that we could say, if you design as an industry and itself but it isn't retail, it's just the online portion of retail. So I don't think they wouldn't a treat to banks of the outset. It would be after they'd taken advantage of all their other scale advantages that they begin to post a threat.

It's also, think about the fact in their healthcare they are partnering with JPMorgan Chase.

FOX: Indeed.

KIRKPATRICK: Right? What about that?

FOX: Yes, never of the information that they can put together with the joint venture with JPMorgan Chase.

Much appreciated, David Kirkpatrick, he is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy, also the author of the book, the "Facebook Effect."

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6R-VY21-DXH2-63VD-00000-00David Kirkpatrick is interviewed on BB Surveillance2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:57ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE7:00 AM ESTDavid Kirkpatrick, Lisa AbramowiczNEWSInternational090660cb.556David Kirkpatrick is interviewed on BB SurveillancePimm Fox

David Kirkpatrick discusses technology

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Our next guest is David Kirkpatrick. He is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect" and we want to find out what the congressional effect of yesterday's testimony of Chief Operating Officer, Sheryl Sandberg for Facebook as well as Jack Dorsey the Chief Executive of Twitter may have had on investor's appetite for both of these companies.

David, what did you make of their presentation before Congress and what do you think investor ought to take away?

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND FOUNDER OF TECHONOMY MEDIA: Well, thanks Pimm. I wasn't -- well, you know, it's a different thing for each company. And I think that Jack Dorsey and Sheryl Sandberg take a quite different view of the whole thing. I think the company has came out of it well, in the sense I would call the more or less on this case and that's partly because with Google not showing up a lot of heat was taken off them and put on Google simply for its failure to show.

I also think they were more or less stared the toughest question that might have hope they would asked.

FOX: Such as?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, you know, why did this happen? And why is -- you know, considering that the New York Times had published an article today before, which unfortunately hadn't gone in the print paper that I'm aware of about Libya and how warlords are using it to target each other and selling on is what Facebook et cetera. You know, it just gives us the show how absolutely unprepared they continue to be for the scale of abuse to their platform.

And you know, you have to ask if it's happening there, what's still happening here that we just don't know about yet. The problem with this platform is they're so abusable that there are essentially infinite ways to gain their system and they have enormous distribution power. And therefore they become weaponized and they're trying desperately to deal with that and I do admire and respect many of the gestures they're taking and the people they've hired to try to step up to the problem but they have not yet fully step up to the problem. And I think it's very different from Twitter than for Facebook though.

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: You know, it's interesting you talked about how unprepared they are for this. I was sort of shocked that they weren't grilled more on this subject of the actual panel which was the security issue and foreign agents using their platforms. So there's a lack of scrutiny over the topic of the actual hearing suggest to you that there's going to be zero asking from a congressional standpoint on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Probably you're right about that. I would say that's very good speculation. You know, theoretically what we really were expecting was keep probing about Russian manipulation in particular and what is being put in place to prevent it from harming the election this fall.

We didn't really hear that in any great detail. We heard a lot of -- in my opinion fairly rode statements that have the same thing that have been said in public before by Sheryl Sandberg. And I think Jack Dorsey more candidly and with a more humility acknowledge the Twitter really isn't yet doing enough and to some extent doesn't even know what to do.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: The different thing, the two companies in my opinion, is that Facebook desperately wants to convey the notion that they have this in hand. Jack doesn't have that arrogance. He also doesn't have the money to even make that claim because Twitter is so much less profitable and so much smart. But you know, in Mark Zuckerberg with Kara Swisher month or so ago, he actually said the problem would be solved by the end of 2019 with artificial intelligence.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Go back and check it out. I mean, that just totally wrong and really naive and dangerous. Sheryl didn't say that exactly yesterday but she really less -- you know, this thing it's on us that we want to prepare to be as a very back candid way of accepting responsibility.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: He doesn't really say, oh my gosh, we are ashamed that we built the platform that did not have sufficient controls and protections against abuse. We are desperately trying to fix it. We don't fully know how we need your help government outside civil society, please help us, that what they should be saying.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I'm really glad you said that, David, because -- I think I don't know about Pimm, but I know that when I was listening to the testimony I found Jack Dorsey to be a lot more humble and thoughtful about his answers and I thought Sheryl Sandberg was very practiced and very polished but it felt like she was reading the script that she had been giving or she drafted ahead of time. And I feel like David, you're kind of reiterating that feeling even though when we talked with the people yesterday they thought that Sheryl Sandberg had done the better job and certainly that seems to be what the stock action reflected. What's your view on that?

KIRKPATRICK: You just restated exactly what I believe. I think Sheryl is a very-scripted, relatively insincere public speaker particularly at this point. I think much of the problem that happen on Facebook that have lead to this manipulation and abuse of Facebook in the United States and Germany, in Brexit and so many other instances really are a consequence of the failure to build controls into the advertising system that she over saw.

Therefore she is personally responsible for many of the thing that went wrong. And she essentially escaping any kind of real accounting for that and nobody -- because that's unfortunately even though some have said yesterday Senate question showed more intelligence and I thought Senator Warner actually on Bloomberg bragging about how he thought that this committee has smarter questions than the hearing when Zuckerberg was testifying. I really don't think that on balance the senators really understand how the stuff all works and who is responsible. And, you know, what any of the mechanics are inside the company. And that's partly because Facebook has been consummately un-transparent. I mean, they really do not show any real humility, zero. And that is a big difference with Jack Dorsey.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick --

KIRKPATRICK: They don't know what they're doing.

FOX: OK. Look into the future and we're going to continue the conversation. I just want you to look into the future for us, maybe 5, maybe even a decade from now. Do you believe that there will be government regulations that in some way affect social media technology?

KIRKPATRICK: 100%. I would say it's a lot less than 10 years. We're talking about two-year probably and it will be very fragmented global regulatory environment that they're going to be getting regulation all over the place where we're seeing that in Europe quite dramatically. It's happening. It will happen here, totally.

FOX: And maybe investors are already picking up on that because I just looking at the trading in Facebook shares, they are down now heading for the fifth consecutive trading session of losses, Facebook shares are now lower on the year, they are down about six percent.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes. We're going to continue conversation with David Kirkpatrick. So stay where you are, because we can talk about Facebook. Facebook is actually the one laggard among all of them that is down on the air. People talk about the same rally and how that's really driven stock market. Well, certainly Facebook has been entirely left out of that and sort of interesting to see in question whether it's the sort of lack of stability that David Kirkpatrick was talking about that perhaps lead into that.

FOX: Well compare to the performance of Twitter and not to say that the stock performance is a proxy for whether the companies are going to be regulator or not but Twitter shares they're up more than 30% this year, compare that to Facebook, the shares as I said they are down about six in quarter percent so far this year.

We've got much more with David Kirkpatrick of Techonomy and also the author of the "Facebook Effect" talking about what happens when government regulator make it very interested in your business.

(BREAK)

FOX: Our guest is David Kirkpatrick, he is the founder and the chief executive of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect."

David, I'm going to have you put three Ph.D. dissertations into a very short amount of time. I want to get your thoughts on robotics artificial intelligence and machine learning. Are these are just buzz words or are we going to have to learn more details about the companies that create this kind of technology?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, those are huge, huge issues that are all deeply connected. Certainly, machine learning is a significant subset of artificial intelligence and robotics is increasingly control by artificial intelligence.

We are going to see these technologies and particularly A.I. in general become a more and more central part of how systems work around everything we do in our personal lives, in our work lives, in industrial circumstances in government, everywhere it's just the direction that technology is heading including even in the area we were discussing for social media where it's -- you know A.I. is said to be the technology that will solve the problem by some practitioners. So yes, it's huge. These are the technologies to watch.

ABRAMOWICZ: So what's the company -- which companies are the ones to watch who are best sort of adopting machine learning and artificial intelligence to practical applications and will be a commercial success who haven't already been recognize?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, the interesting thing about that is it's not a surprising answer. There are a lot of small companies that are doing very innovative thing in terms of the actual software but the key with A.I. to make it successful is that scale of the dataset that you have to work with which then you use to train "machine learning" which takes, you know, continued passes over a decision making process with more and more and more data and gets better and better.

So therefore the people who have the most data who are also working on A.I. are the ones who will win and that basically limited to a very small group, which is Amazon, Facebook, Google, Microsoft to a lesser extend, Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu, you know, there are companies that have a very good -- their main expertise in certain fields like Uber and self-driving and, you know, delivery of humans and other things but in general I would say the companies that are going to win on A.I. are Amazon, Facebook and Google must of all.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, full disclosure I have the pressure of attending one of your Techonomy sessions and I learned that companies such as SAP Oracle, those people that are in the background of all of these databases particularly for industrial applications they are also making Artificial Intelligence in the mining of data a key stone of their strategy to help their costumers. Can you elaborate on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, certainly and SAP is an example of a very large company that also has access to an awful lot of data and they're working really hard with A.I. So it's not to say they aren't doing smart stuff. It's similarly salesforce.com, Oracle as you mentioned, IBM is of course a company who is watching product for several years, kind of leading their charge of image management and they are talking more about A.I. and lesson about watching now but certainly IBM believes A.I. is key to a future.

You know, I wouldn't think it's over stating it to say every technology company and consumer or enterprise oriented software and services recognizes that A.I. is probably the central technology that will determine whether they win or not. It's how well do you deploy A.I. and A.I. solutions, whether you're building yourself or you are buying it and deploying it that was built by others.

One of the things that I think we probably will see going back to what I said before about Amazon and other is that especially we get Amazon Google and Microsoft all offer their own cloud hosting services, they will be able to offer A.I. services as part of their cloud services to enterprise customers and start aps and that is going to be a key differentiator that they will use to try to compete with one another. And again, Amazon, being the largest has the biggest advantage thought.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I have to wonder as you talk, David, as you were saying earlier about the big tech giants winning just simply due to the scope of the data that they have. Will this scrunch (ph) to innovation? In other words, without democratization of that data and of that power, that ability to try to come up with the best algorithms and the best machine learning processes, are we going not get necessarily the best ideas?

KIRKPATRICK: No, in a sense it's the scale of these companies to begin with that is at risk of scrunching innovation or concentrating it unfairly. I think that -- this is I believe and I think goes to the hearing yesterday and why it was somewhat disappointed (ph) them.

The few scale of Facebook, Google and Amazon in particular is such a new development in society and so overwhelming the important from so many aspects because there's -- the power they have to control economics activity to gain insight into social and societal and even governmental function to develop A.I. So the A.I. piece is just one part of that but yes, this companies had an unfair advantage because of the scale and, you know, it's one the reason why Jeff Bezos is the richest man in the world, worth of $160 -- $170 billion, the market has recognize that.

But it's very intertwined set of issues that have super complicated. It is a big topic for us to Techonomy and I'm glad that Pimm mentioned what we're doing here because we really think that the Techonomy host conference and publishes stuff on our website, Techonomy.com, et cetera.

This whole issue of A.I. has impacted influence in long-term implications and this is simultaneous of the scale of the small number of companies. These are some of the biggest strategic questions that not only business but society has rustled with.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, to get a little bit more in the weeds because Amazon and the Amazon factor always in the background when it comes to any kind of commercial enterprise now whether it's web services, you described or retail and indeed even the healthcare initiative, what do you believe will be the next industry to be disrupted by Amazon?

KIRKPATRICK: One that I would be pretty seriously expecting is banking. They've got -- and I would say, probably they've got their eyes on insurance as well. I mean, the healthcare thing is still very nascent but they did hire a very immanent healthcare writer and research doctor to work them and at JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway on a kind of overall sort of employee oriented project to begin with --

FOX: Right. But do you think insurance and banking, the finance industry?

KIRKPATRICK: Oh, yeah. I mean, look, think of how much banking inspiration Amazon must already had given the scale of commerce that is being concentrated through its platform. You know, it's getting enormous influence. I mean, certainly it offers credit card services are at various sorts and partnership with others now.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: And that's just the beginning. You know, the economy is going digital. So the digital dominant companies are going to have an advantage in almost every industry.

ABRAMOWICZ: But don't think want to avoid the regulation, the oversight that comes along with paying a bank?

KIRKPATRICK: Maybe. Maybe not. I mean, I think Amazon and Jeff Bezos is -- this is one thing he does share with Elon Musk is fearlessness and a willingness to confront unexpected, you know, obstacles and just sort of power through. I don't think that a fear of banking regulation would stop Amazon what the insight that they really wanted to get into that.

I think what would stop and potentially is the fear of antitrust or some kind of new regulatory oversight that they're disparate to avoid but again, the conventional antitrust doesn't even really apply because Amazon tacticals (ph) are in so many industry simultaneously that they're gaining additional scale without actually dominating anyone industry.

I mean, they do dominate online retails so that we could say, if you design as an industry and itself but it isn't retail, it's just the online portion of retail. So I don't think they wouldn't a treat to banks of the outset. It would be after they'd taken advantage of all their other scale advantages that they begin to post a threat.

It's also, think about the fact in their healthcare they are partnering with JPMorgan Chase.

FOX: Indeed.

KIRKPATRICK: Right? What about that?

FOX: Yes, never of the information that they can put together with the joint venture with JPMorgan Chase.

Much appreciated, David Kirkpatrick, he is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy, also the author of the book, the "Facebook Effect."

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5T6X-RXH1-JBHT-D1RG-00000-00David Kirkpatrick is interviewed on BB Surveillance2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:57ZLexisNexisDavid Kirkpatrick is interviewed on BB SurveillanceLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Our next guest is David Kirkpatrick. He is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect" and we want to find out what the congressional effect of yesterday's testimony of Chief Operating Officer, Sheryl Sandberg for Facebook as well as Jack Dorsey the Chief Executive of Twitter may have had on investor's appetite for both of these companies.

David, what did you make of their presentation before Congress and what do you think investor ought to take away?

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND FOUNDER OF TECHONOMY MEDIA: Well, thanks Pimm. I wasn't -- well, you know, it's a different thing for each company. And I think that Jack Dorsey and Sheryl Sandberg take a quite different view of the whole thing. I think the company has came out of it well, in the sense I would call the more or less on this case and that's partly because with Google not showing up a lot of heat was taken off them and put on Google simply for its failure to show.

I also think they were more or less stared the toughest question that might have hope they would asked.

FOX: Such as?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, you know, why did this happen? And why is -- you know, considering that the New York Times had published an article today before, which unfortunately hadn't gone in the print paper that I'm aware of about Libya and how warlords are using it to target each other and selling on is what Facebook et cetera. You know, it just gives us the show how absolutely unprepared they continue to be for the scale of abuse to their platform.

And you know, you have to ask if it's happening there, what's still happening here that we just don't know about yet. The problem with this platform is they're so abusable that there are essentially infinite ways to gain their system and they have enormous distribution power. And therefore they become weaponized and they're trying desperately to deal with that and I do admire and respect many of the gestures they're taking and the people they've hired to try to step up to the problem but they have not yet fully step up to the problem. And I think it's very different from Twitter than for Facebook though.

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: You know, it's interesting you talked about how unprepared they are for this. I was sort of shocked that they weren't grilled more on this subject of the actual panel which was the security issue and foreign agents using their platforms. So there's a lack of scrutiny over the topic of the actual hearing suggest to you that there's going to be zero asking from a congressional standpoint on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Probably you're right about that. I would say that's very good speculation. You know, theoretically what we really were expecting was keep probing about Russian manipulation in particular and what is being put in place to prevent it from harming the election this fall.

We didn't really hear that in any great detail. We heard a lot of -- in my opinion fairly rode statements that have the same thing that have been said in public before by Sheryl Sandberg. And I think Jack Dorsey more candidly and with a more humility acknowledge the Twitter really isn't yet doing enough and to some extent doesn't even know what to do.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: The different thing, the two companies in my opinion, is that Facebook desperately wants to convey the notion that they have this in hand. Jack doesn't have that arrogance. He also doesn't have the money to even make that claim because Twitter is so much less profitable and so much smart. But you know, in Mark Zuckerberg with Kara Swisher month or so ago, he actually said the problem would be solved by the end of 2019 with artificial intelligence.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Go back and check it out. I mean, that just totally wrong and really naive and dangerous. Sheryl didn't say that exactly yesterday but she really less -- you know, this thing it's on us that we want to prepare to be as a very back candid way of accepting responsibility.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: He doesn't really say, oh my gosh, we are ashamed that we built the platform that did not have sufficient controls and protections against abuse. We are desperately trying to fix it. We don't fully know how we need your help government outside civil society, please help us, that what they should be saying.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I'm really glad you said that, David, because -- I think I don't know about Pimm, but I know that when I was listening to the testimony I found Jack Dorsey to be a lot more humble and thoughtful about his answers and I thought Sheryl Sandberg was very practiced and very polished but it felt like she was reading the script that she had been giving or she drafted ahead of time. And I feel like David, you're kind of reiterating that feeling even though when we talked with the people yesterday they thought that Sheryl Sandberg had done the better job and certainly that seems to be what the stock action reflected. What's your view on that?

KIRKPATRICK: You just restated exactly what I believe. I think Sheryl is a very-scripted, relatively insincere public speaker particularly at this point. I think much of the problem that happen on Facebook that have lead to this manipulation and abuse of Facebook in the United States and Germany, in Brexit and so many other instances really are a consequence of the failure to build controls into the advertising system that she over saw.

Therefore she is personally responsible for many of the thing that went wrong. And she essentially escaping any kind of real accounting for that and nobody -- because that's unfortunately even though some have said yesterday Senate question showed more intelligence and I thought Senator Warner actually on Bloomberg bragging about how he thought that this committee has smarter questions than the hearing when Zuckerberg was testifying. I really don't think that on balance the senators really understand how the stuff all works and who is responsible. And, you know, what any of the mechanics are inside the company. And that's partly because Facebook has been consummately un-transparent. I mean, they really do not show any real humility, zero. And that is a big difference with Jack Dorsey.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick --

KIRKPATRICK: They don't know what they're doing.

FOX: OK. Look into the future and we're going to continue the conversation. I just want you to look into the future for us, maybe 5, maybe even a decade from now. Do you believe that there will be government regulations that in some way affect social media technology?

KIRKPATRICK: 100%. I would say it's a lot less than 10 years. We're talking about two-year probably and it will be very fragmented global regulatory environment that they're going to be getting regulation all over the place where we're seeing that in Europe quite dramatically. It's happening. It will happen here, totally.

FOX: And maybe investors are already picking up on that because I just looking at the trading in Facebook shares, they are down now heading for the fifth consecutive trading session of losses, Facebook shares are now lower on the year, they are down about six percent.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes. We're going to continue conversation with David Kirkpatrick. So stay where you are, because we can talk about Facebook. Facebook is actually the one laggard among all of them that is down on the air. People talk about the same rally and how that's really driven stock market. Well, certainly Facebook has been entirely left out of that and sort of interesting to see in question whether it's the sort of lack of stability that David Kirkpatrick was talking about that perhaps lead into that.

FOX: Well compare to the performance of Twitter and not to say that the stock performance is a proxy for whether the companies are going to be regulator or not but Twitter shares they're up more than 30% this year, compare that to Facebook, the shares as I said they are down about six in quarter percent so far this year.

We've got much more with David Kirkpatrick of Techonomy and also the author of the "Facebook Effect" talking about what happens when government regulator make it very interested in your business.

(BREAK)

FOX: Our guest is David Kirkpatrick, he is the founder and the chief executive of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect."

David, I'm going to have you put three Ph.D. dissertations into a very short amount of time. I want to get your thoughts on robotics artificial intelligence and machine learning. Are these are just buzz words or are we going to have to learn more details about the companies that create this kind of technology?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, those are huge, huge issues that are all deeply connected. Certainly, machine learning is a significant subset of artificial intelligence and robotics is increasingly control by artificial intelligence.

We are going to see these technologies and particularly A.I. in general become a more and more central part of how systems work around everything we do in our personal lives, in our work lives, in industrial circumstances in government, everywhere it's just the direction that technology is heading including even in the area we were discussing for social media where it's -- you know A.I. is said to be the technology that will solve the problem by some practitioners. So yes, it's huge. These are the technologies to watch.

ABRAMOWICZ: So what's the company -- which companies are the ones to watch who are best sort of adopting machine learning and artificial intelligence to practical applications and will be a commercial success who haven't already been recognize?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, the interesting thing about that is it's not a surprising answer. There are a lot of small companies that are doing very innovative thing in terms of the actual software but the key with A.I. to make it successful is that scale of the dataset that you have to work with which then you use to train "machine learning" which takes, you know, continued passes over a decision making process with more and more and more data and gets better and better.

So therefore the people who have the most data who are also working on A.I. are the ones who will win and that basically limited to a very small group, which is Amazon, Facebook, Google, Microsoft to a lesser extend, Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu, you know, there are companies that have a very good -- their main expertise in certain fields like Uber and self-driving and, you know, delivery of humans and other things but in general I would say the companies that are going to win on A.I. are Amazon, Facebook and Google must of all.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, full disclosure I have the pressure of attending one of your Techonomy sessions and I learned that companies such as SAPOracle, those people that are in the background of all of these databases particularly for industrial applications they are also making Artificial Intelligence in the mining of data a key stone of their strategy to help their costumers. Can you elaborate on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, certainly and SAP is an example of a very large company that also has access to an awful lot of data and they're working really hard with A.I. So it's not to say they aren't doing smart stuff. It's similarly salesforce.com, Oracle as you mentioned, IBM is of course a company who is watching product for several years, kind of leading their charge of image management and they are talking more about A.I. and lesson about watching now but certainly IBM believes A.I. is key to a future.

You know, I wouldn't think it's over stating it to say every technology company and consumer or enterprise oriented software and services recognizes that A.I. is probably the central technology that will determine whether they win or not. It's how well do you deploy A.I. and A.I. solutions, whether you're building yourself or you are buying it and deploying it that was built by others.

One of the things that I think we probably will see going back to what I said before about Amazon and other is that especially we get AmazonGoogle and Microsoft all offer their own cloud hosting services, they will be able to offer A.I. services as part of their cloud services to enterprise customers and start aps and that is going to be a key differentiator that they will use to try to compete with one another. And again, Amazon, being the largest has the biggest advantage thought.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I have to wonder as you talk, David, as you were saying earlier about the big tech giants winning just simply due to the scope of the data that they have. Will this scrunch (ph) to innovation? In other words, without democratization of that data and of that power, that ability to try to come up with the best algorithms and the best machine learning processes, are we going not get necessarily the best ideas?

KIRKPATRICK: No, in a sense it's the scale of these companies to begin with that is at risk of scrunching innovation or concentrating it unfairly. I think that -- this is I believe and I think goes to the hearing yesterday and why it was somewhat disappointed (ph) them.

The few scale of Facebook, Google and Amazon in particular is such a new development in society and so overwhelming the important from so many aspects because there's -- the power they have to control economics activity to gain insight into social and societal and even governmental function to develop A.I. So the A.I. piece is just one part of that but yes, this companies had an unfair advantage because of the scale and, you know, it's one the reason why Jeff Bezos is the richest man in the world, worth of $160 -- $170 billion, the market has recognize that.

But it's very intertwined set of issues that have super complicated. It is a big topic for us to Techonomy and I'm glad that Pimm mentioned what we're doing here because we really think that the Techonomy host conference and publishes stuff on our website, Techonomy.com, et cetera.

This whole issue of A.I. has impacted influence in long-term implications and this is simultaneous of the scale of the small number of companies. These are some of the biggest strategic questions that not only business but society has rustled with.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, to get a little bit more in the weeds because Amazon and the Amazon factor always in the background when it comes to any kind of commercial enterprise now whether it's web services, you described or retail and indeed even the healthcare initiative, what do you believe will be the next industry to be disrupted by Amazon?

KIRKPATRICK: One that I would be pretty seriously expecting is banking. They've got -- and I would say, probably they've got their eyes on insurance as well. I mean, the healthcare thing is still very nascent but they did hire a very immanent healthcare writer and research doctor to work them and at JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway on a kind of overall sort of employee oriented project to begin with --

FOX: Right. But do you think insurance and banking, the finance industry?

KIRKPATRICK: Oh, yeah. I mean, look, think of how much banking inspiration Amazon must already had given the scale of commerce that is being concentrated through its platform. You know, it's getting enormous influence. I mean, certainly it offers credit card services are at various sorts and partnership with others now.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: And that's just the beginning. You know, the economy is going digital. So the digital dominant companies are going to have an advantage in almost every industry.

ABRAMOWICZ: But don't think want to avoid the regulation, the oversight that comes along with paying a bank?

KIRKPATRICK: Maybe. Maybe not. I mean, I think Amazon and Jeff Bezos is -- this is one thing he does share with Elon Musk is fearlessness and a willingness to confront unexpected, you know, obstacles and just sort of power through. I don't think that a fear of banking regulation would stop Amazon what the insight that they really wanted to get into that.

I think what would stop and potentially is the fear of antitrust or some kind of new regulatory oversight that they're disparate to avoid but again, the conventional antitrust doesn't even really apply because Amazon tacticals (ph) are in so many industry simultaneously that they're gaining additional scale without actually dominating anyone industry.

I mean, they do dominate online retails so that we could say, if you design as an industry and itself but it isn't retail, it's just the online portion of retail. So I don't think they wouldn't a treat to banks of the outset. It would be after they'd taken advantage of all their other scale advantages that they begin to post a threat.

It's also, think about the fact in their healthcare they are partnering with JPMorgan Chase.

FOX: Indeed.

KIRKPATRICK: Right? What about that?

FOX: Yes, never of the information that they can put together with the joint venture with JPMorgan Chase.

Much appreciated, David Kirkpatrick, he is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy, also the author of the book, the "Facebook Effect."

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5T6X-RXH1-JBHT-D1RH-00000-00David Kirkpatrick is interviewed on BB Surveillance2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:57ZLexisNexisDavid Kirkpatrick is interviewed on BB SurveillanceWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Our next guest is David Kirkpatrick. He is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect" and we want to find out what the congressional effect of yesterday's testimony of Chief Operating Officer, Sheryl Sandberg for Facebook as well as Jack Dorsey the Chief Executive of Twitter may have had on investor's appetite for both of these companies.

David, what did you make of their presentation before Congress and what do you think investor ought to take away?

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND FOUNDER OF TECHONOMY MEDIA: Well, thanks Pimm. I wasn't -- well, you know, it's a different thing for each company. And I think that Jack Dorsey and Sheryl Sandberg take a quite different view of the whole thing. I think the company has came out of it well, in the sense I would call the more or less on this case and that's partly because with Google not showing up a lot of heat was taken off them and put on Google simply for its failure to show.

I also think they were more or less stared the toughest question that might have hope they would asked.

FOX: Such as?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, you know, why did this happen? And why is -- you know, considering that the New York Times had published an article today before, which unfortunately hadn't gone in the print paper that I'm aware of about Libya and how warlords are using it to target each other and selling on is what Facebook et cetera. You know, it just gives us the show how absolutely unprepared they continue to be for the scale of abuse to their platform.

And you know, you have to ask if it's happening there, what's still happening here that we just don't know about yet. The problem with this platform is they're so abusable that there are essentially infinite ways to gain their system and they have enormous distribution power. And therefore they become weaponized and they're trying desperately to deal with that and I do admire and respect many of the gestures they're taking and the people they've hired to try to step up to the problem but they have not yet fully step up to the problem. And I think it's very different from Twitter than for Facebook though.

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: You know, it's interesting you talked about how unprepared they are for this. I was sort of shocked that they weren't grilled more on this subject of the actual panel which was the security issue and foreign agents using their platforms. So there's a lack of scrutiny over the topic of the actual hearing suggest to you that there's going to be zero asking from a congressional standpoint on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Probably you're right about that. I would say that's very good speculation. You know, theoretically what we really were expecting was keep probing about Russian manipulation in particular and what is being put in place to prevent it from harming the election this fall.

We didn't really hear that in any great detail. We heard a lot of -- in my opinion fairly rode statements that have the same thing that have been said in public before by Sheryl Sandberg. And I think Jack Dorsey more candidly and with a more humility acknowledge the Twitter really isn't yet doing enough and to some extent doesn't even know what to do.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: The different thing, the two companies in my opinion, is that Facebook desperately wants to convey the notion that they have this in hand. Jack doesn't have that arrogance. He also doesn't have the money to even make that claim because Twitter is so much less profitable and so much smart. But you know, in Mark Zuckerberg with Kara Swisher month or so ago, he actually said the problem would be solved by the end of 2019 with artificial intelligence.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Go back and check it out. I mean, that just totally wrong and really naive and dangerous. Sheryl didn't say that exactly yesterday but she really less -- you know, this thing it's on us that we want to prepare to be as a very back candid way of accepting responsibility.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: He doesn't really say, oh my gosh, we are ashamed that we built the platform that did not have sufficient controls and protections against abuse. We are desperately trying to fix it. We don't fully know how we need your help government outside civil society, please help us, that what they should be saying.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I'm really glad you said that, David, because -- I think I don't know about Pimm, but I know that when I was listening to the testimony I found Jack Dorsey to be a lot more humble and thoughtful about his answers and I thought Sheryl Sandberg was very practiced and very polished but it felt like she was reading the script that she had been giving or she drafted ahead of time. And I feel like David, you're kind of reiterating that feeling even though when we talked with the people yesterday they thought that Sheryl Sandberg had done the better job and certainly that seems to be what the stock action reflected. What's your view on that?

KIRKPATRICK: You just restated exactly what I believe. I think Sheryl is a very-scripted, relatively insincere public speaker particularly at this point. I think much of the problem that happen on Facebook that have lead to this manipulation and abuse of Facebook in the United States and Germany, in Brexit and so many other instances really are a consequence of the failure to build controls into the advertising system that she over saw.

Therefore she is personally responsible for many of the thing that went wrong. And she essentially escaping any kind of real accounting for that and nobody -- because that's unfortunately even though some have said yesterday Senate question showed more intelligence and I thought Senator Warner actually on Bloomberg bragging about how he thought that this committee has smarter questions than the hearing when Zuckerberg was testifying. I really don't think that on balance the senators really understand how the stuff all works and who is responsible. And, you know, what any of the mechanics are inside the company. And that's partly because Facebook has been consummately un-transparent. I mean, they really do not show any real humility, zero. And that is a big difference with Jack Dorsey.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick --

KIRKPATRICK: They don't know what they're doing.

FOX: OK. Look into the future and we're going to continue the conversation. I just want you to look into the future for us, maybe 5, maybe even a decade from now. Do you believe that there will be government regulations that in some way affect social media technology?

KIRKPATRICK: 100%. I would say it's a lot less than 10 years. We're talking about two-year probably and it will be very fragmented global regulatory environment that they're going to be getting regulation all over the place where we're seeing that in Europe quite dramatically. It's happening. It will happen here, totally.

FOX: And maybe investors are already picking up on that because I just looking at the trading in Facebook shares, they are down now heading for the fifth consecutive trading session of losses, Facebook shares are now lower on the year, they are down about six percent.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes. We're going to continue conversation with David Kirkpatrick. So stay where you are, because we can talk about Facebook. Facebook is actually the one laggard among all of them that is down on the air. People talk about the same rally and how that's really driven stock market. Well, certainly Facebook has been entirely left out of that and sort of interesting to see in question whether it's the sort of lack of stability that David Kirkpatrick was talking about that perhaps lead into that.

FOX: Well compare to the performance of Twitter and not to say that the stock performance is a proxy for whether the companies are going to be regulator or not but Twitter shares they're up more than 30% this year, compare that to Facebook, the shares as I said they are down about six in quarter percent so far this year.

We've got much more with David Kirkpatrick of Techonomy and also the author of the "Facebook Effect" talking about what happens when government regulator make it very interested in your business.

(BREAK)

KIRKPATRICK: Well, certainly and SAP is an example of a very large company that also has access to an awful lot of data and they're working really hard with A.I. So it's not to say they aren't doing smart stuff. It's similarly salesforce.com, Oracle as you mentioned, IBM is of course a company who is watching product for several years, kind of leading their charge of image management and they are talking more about A.I. and lesson about watching now but certainly IBM believes A.I. is key to a future.

You know, I wouldn't think it's over stating it to say every technology company and consumer or enterprise oriented software and services recognizes that A.I. is probably the central technology that will determine whether they win or not. It's how well do you deploy A.I. and A.I. solutions, whether you're building yourself or you are buying it and deploying it that was built by others.

One of the things that I think we probably will see going back to what I said before about Amazon and other is that especially we get Amazon Google and Microsoft all offer their own cloud hosting services, they will be able to offer A.I. services as part of their cloud services to enterprise customers and start aps and that is going to be a key differentiator that they will use to try to compete with one another. And again, Amazon, being the largest has the biggest advantage thought.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I have to wonder as you talk, David, as you were saying earlier about the big tech giants winning just simply due to the scope of the data that they have. Will this scrunch (ph) to innovation? In other words, without democratization of that data and of that power, that ability to try to come up with the best algorithms and the best machine learning processes, are we going not get necessarily the best ideas?

KIRKPATRICK: No, in a sense it's the scale of these companies to begin with that is at risk of scrunching innovation or concentrating it unfairly. I think that -- this is I believe and I think goes to the hearing yesterday and why it was somewhat disappointed (ph) them.

The few scale of Facebook, Google and Amazon in particular is such a new development in society and so overwhelming the important from so many aspects because there's -- the power they have to control economics activity to gain insight into social and societal and even governmental function to develop A.I. So the A.I. piece is just one part of that but yes, this companies had an unfair advantage because of the scale and, you know, it's one the reason why Jeff Bezos is the richest man in the world, worth of $160 -- $170 billion, the market has recognize that.

But it's very intertwined set of issues that have super complicated. It is a big topic for us to Techonomy and I'm glad that Pimm mentioned what we're doing here because we really think that the Techonomy host conference and publishes stuff on our website, Techonomy.com, et cetera.

This whole issue of A.I. has impacted influence in long-term implications and this is simultaneous of the scale of the small number of companies. These are some of the biggest strategic questions that not only business but society has rustled with.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, to get a little bit more in the weeds because Amazon and the Amazon factor always in the background when it comes to any kind of commercial enterprise now whether it's web services, you described or retail and indeed even the healthcare initiative, what do you believe will be the next industry to be disrupted by Amazon?

KIRKPATRICK: One that I would be pretty seriously expecting is banking. They've got -- and I would say, probably they've got their eyes on insurance as well. I mean, the healthcare thing is still very nascent but they did hire a very immanent healthcare writer and research doctor to work them and at JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway on a kind of overall sort of employee oriented project to begin with --

FOX: Right. But do you think insurance and banking, the finance industry?

KIRKPATRICK: Oh, yeah. I mean, look, think of how much banking inspiration Amazon must already had given the scale of commerce that is being concentrated through its platform. You know, it's getting enormous influence. I mean, certainly it offers credit card services are at various sorts and partnership with others now.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: And that's just the beginning. You know, the economy is going digital. So the digital dominant companies are going to have an advantage in almost every industry.

ABRAMOWICZ: But don't think want to avoid the regulation, the oversight that comes along with paying a bank?

KIRKPATRICK: Maybe. Maybe not. I mean, I think Amazon and Jeff Bezos is -- this is one thing he does share with Elon Musk is fearlessness and a willingness to confront unexpected, you know, obstacles and just sort of power through. I don't think that a fear of banking regulation would stop Amazon what the insight that they really wanted to get into that.

I think what would stop and potentially is the fear of antitrust or some kind of new regulatory oversight that they're disparate to avoid but again, the conventional antitrust doesn't even really apply because Amazon tacticals (ph) are in so many industry simultaneously that they're gaining additional scale without actually dominating anyone industry.

I mean, they do dominate online retails so that we could say, if you design as an industry and itself but it isn't retail, it's just the online portion of retail. So I don't think they wouldn't a treat to banks of the outset. It would be after they'd taken advantage of all their other scale advantages that they begin to post a threat.

It's also, think about the fact in their healthcare they are partnering with JPMorgan Chase.

FOX: Indeed.

KIRKPATRICK: Right? What about that?

FOX: Yes, never of the information that they can put together with the joint venture with JPMorgan Chase.

Much appreciated, David Kirkpatrick, he is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy, also the author of the book, the "Facebook Effect."

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
