Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6R-VY21-DXH2-63VF-00000-00David Kirkpatrick is interviewed on BB Surveillance2018-09-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:57ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE7:00 AM ESTDavid Kirkpatrick, Lisa AbramowiczNEWSInternational090660cb.556David Kirkpatrick is interviewed on BB SurveillancePimm Fox

David Kirkpatrick discusses technology

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

PIMM FOX, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Our next guest is David Kirkpatrick. He is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect" and we want to find out what the congressional effect of yesterday's testimony of Chief Operating Officer, Sheryl Sandberg for Facebook as well as Jack Dorsey the Chief Executive of Twitter may have had on investor's appetite for both of these companies.

David, what did you make of their presentation before Congress and what do you think investor ought to take away?

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND FOUNDER OF TECHONOMY MEDIA: Well, thanks Pimm. I wasn't -- well, you know, it's a different thing for each company. And I think that Jack Dorsey and Sheryl Sandberg take a quite different view of the whole thing. I think the company has came out of it well, in the sense I would call the more or less on this case and that's partly because with Google not showing up a lot of heat was taken off them and put on Google simply for its failure to show.

I also think they were more or less stared the toughest question that might have hope they would asked.

FOX: Such as?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, you know, why did this happen? And why is -- you know, considering that the New York Times had published an article today before, which unfortunately hadn't gone in the print paper that I'm aware of about Libya and how warlords are using it to target each other and selling on is what Facebook et cetera. You know, it just gives us the show how absolutely unprepared they continue to be for the scale of abuse to their platform.

And you know, you have to ask if it's happening there, what's still happening here that we just don't know about yet. The problem with this platform is they're so abusable that there are essentially infinite ways to gain their system and they have enormous distribution power. And therefore they become weaponized and they're trying desperately to deal with that and I do admire and respect many of the gestures they're taking and the people they've hired to try to step up to the problem but they have not yet fully step up to the problem. And I think it's very different from Twitter than for Facebook though.

LISA ABRAMOWICZ, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: You know, it's interesting you talked about how unprepared they are for this. I was sort of shocked that they weren't grilled more on this subject of the actual panel which was the security issue and foreign agents using their platforms. So there's a lack of scrutiny over the topic of the actual hearing suggest to you that there's going to be zero asking from a congressional standpoint on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Probably you're right about that. I would say that's very good speculation. You know, theoretically what we really were expecting was keep probing about Russian manipulation in particular and what is being put in place to prevent it from harming the election this fall.

We didn't really hear that in any great detail. We heard a lot of -- in my opinion fairly rode statements that have the same thing that have been said in public before by Sheryl Sandberg. And I think Jack Dorsey more candidly and with a more humility acknowledge the Twitter really isn't yet doing enough and to some extent doesn't even know what to do.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: The different thing, the two companies in my opinion, is that Facebook desperately wants to convey the notion that they have this in hand. Jack doesn't have that arrogance. He also doesn't have the money to even make that claim because Twitter is so much less profitable and so much smart. But you know, in Mark Zuckerberg with Kara Swisher month or so ago, he actually said the problem would be solved by the end of 2019 with artificial intelligence.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Go back and check it out. I mean, that just totally wrong and really naive and dangerous. Sheryl didn't say that exactly yesterday but she really less -- you know, this thing it's on us that we want to prepare to be as a very back candid way of accepting responsibility.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: He doesn't really say, oh my gosh, we are ashamed that we built the platform that did not have sufficient controls and protections against abuse. We are desperately trying to fix it. We don't fully know how we need your help government outside civil society, please help us, that what they should be saying.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I'm really glad you said that, David, because -- I think I don't know about Pimm, but I know that when I was listening to the testimony I found Jack Dorsey to be a lot more humble and thoughtful about his answers and I thought Sheryl Sandberg was very practiced and very polished but it felt like she was reading the script that she had been giving or she drafted ahead of time. And I feel like David, you're kind of reiterating that feeling even though when we talked with the people yesterday they thought that Sheryl Sandberg had done the better job and certainly that seems to be what the stock action reflected. What's your view on that?

KIRKPATRICK: You just restated exactly what I believe. I think Sheryl is a very-scripted, relatively insincere public speaker particularly at this point. I think much of the problem that happen on Facebook that have lead to this manipulation and abuse of Facebook in the United States and Germany, in Brexit and so many other instances really are a consequence of the failure to build controls into the advertising system that she over saw.

Therefore she is personally responsible for many of the thing that went wrong. And she essentially escaping any kind of real accounting for that and nobody -- because that's unfortunately even though some have said yesterday Senate question showed more intelligence and I thought Senator Warner actually on Bloomberg bragging about how he thought that this committee has smarter questions than the hearing when Zuckerberg was testifying. I really don't think that on balance the senators really understand how the stuff all works and who is responsible. And, you know, what any of the mechanics are inside the company. And that's partly because Facebook has been consummately un-transparent. I mean, they really do not show any real humility, zero. And that is a big difference with Jack Dorsey.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick --

KIRKPATRICK: They don't know what they're doing.

FOX: OK. Look into the future and we're going to continue the conversation. I just want you to look into the future for us, maybe 5, maybe even a decade from now. Do you believe that there will be government regulations that in some way affect social media technology?

KIRKPATRICK: 100%. I would say it's a lot less than 10 years. We're talking about two-year probably and it will be very fragmented global regulatory environment that they're going to be getting regulation all over the place where we're seeing that in Europe quite dramatically. It's happening. It will happen here, totally.

FOX: And maybe investors are already picking up on that because I just looking at the trading in Facebook shares, they are down now heading for the fifth consecutive trading session of losses, Facebook shares are now lower on the year, they are down about six percent.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes. We're going to continue conversation with David Kirkpatrick. So stay where you are, because we can talk about Facebook. Facebook is actually the one laggard among all of them that is down on the air. People talk about the same rally and how that's really driven stock market. Well, certainly Facebook has been entirely left out of that and sort of interesting to see in question whether it's the sort of lack of stability that David Kirkpatrick was talking about that perhaps lead into that.

FOX: Well compare to the performance of Twitter and not to say that the stock performance is a proxy for whether the companies are going to be regulator or not but Twitter shares they're up more than 30% this year, compare that to Facebook, the shares as I said they are down about six in quarter percent so far this year.

We've got much more with David Kirkpatrick of Techonomy and also the author of the "Facebook Effect" talking about what happens when government regulator make it very interested in your business.

(BREAK)

FOX: Our guest is David Kirkpatrick, he is the founder and the chief executive of Techonomy. He is also the author of the "Facebook Effect."

David, I'm going to have you put three Ph.D. dissertations into a very short amount of time. I want to get your thoughts on robotics artificial intelligence and machine learning. Are these are just buzz words or are we going to have to learn more details about the companies that create this kind of technology?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, those are huge, huge issues that are all deeply connected. Certainly, machine learning is a significant subset of artificial intelligence and robotics is increasingly control by artificial intelligence.

We are going to see these technologies and particularly A.I. in general become a more and more central part of how systems work around everything we do in our personal lives, in our work lives, in industrial circumstances in government, everywhere it's just the direction that technology is heading including even in the area we were discussing for social media where it's -- you know A.I. is said to be the technology that will solve the problem by some practitioners. So yes, it's huge. These are the technologies to watch.

ABRAMOWICZ: So what's the company -- which companies are the ones to watch who are best sort of adopting machine learning and artificial intelligence to practical applications and will be a commercial success who haven't already been recognize?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, the interesting thing about that is it's not a surprising answer. There are a lot of small companies that are doing very innovative thing in terms of the actual software but the key with A.I. to make it successful is that scale of the dataset that you have to work with which then you use to train "machine learning" which takes, you know, continued passes over a decision making process with more and more and more data and gets better and better.

So therefore the people who have the most data who are also working on A.I. are the ones who will win and that basically limited to a very small group, which is Amazon, Facebook, Google, Microsoft to a lesser extend, Alibaba, Tencent, Baidu, you know, there are companies that have a very good -- their main expertise in certain fields like Uber and self-driving and, you know, delivery of humans and other things but in general I would say the companies that are going to win on A.I. are Amazon, Facebook and Google must of all.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, full disclosure I have the pressure of attending one of your Techonomy sessions and I learned that companies such as SAP Oracle, those people that are in the background of all of these databases particularly for industrial applications they are also making Artificial Intelligence in the mining of data a key stone of their strategy to help their costumers. Can you elaborate on that?

KIRKPATRICK: Well, certainly and SAP is an example of a very large company that also has access to an awful lot of data and they're working really hard with A.I. So it's not to say they aren't doing smart stuff. It's similarly salesforce.com, Oracle as you mentioned, IBM is of course a company who is watching product for several years, kind of leading their charge of image management and they are talking more about A.I. and lesson about watching now but certainly IBM believes A.I. is key to a future.

You know, I wouldn't think it's over stating it to say every technology company and consumer or enterprise oriented software and services recognizes that A.I. is probably the central technology that will determine whether they win or not. It's how well do you deploy A.I. and A.I. solutions, whether you're building yourself or you are buying it and deploying it that was built by others.

One of the things that I think we probably will see going back to what I said before about Amazon and other is that especially we get Amazon Google and Microsoft all offer their own cloud hosting services, they will be able to offer A.I. services as part of their cloud services to enterprise customers and start aps and that is going to be a key differentiator that they will use to try to compete with one another. And again, Amazon, being the largest has the biggest advantage thought.

ABRAMOWICZ: You know, I have to wonder as you talk, David, as you were saying earlier about the big tech giants winning just simply due to the scope of the data that they have. Will this scrunch (ph) to innovation? In other words, without democratization of that data and of that power, that ability to try to come up with the best algorithms and the best machine learning processes, are we going not get necessarily the best ideas?

KIRKPATRICK: No, in a sense it's the scale of these companies to begin with that is at risk of scrunching innovation or concentrating it unfairly. I think that -- this is I believe and I think goes to the hearing yesterday and why it was somewhat disappointed (ph) them.

The few scale of Facebook, Google and Amazon in particular is such a new development in society and so overwhelming the important from so many aspects because there's -- the power they have to control economics activity to gain insight into social and societal and even governmental function to develop A.I. So the A.I. piece is just one part of that but yes, this companies had an unfair advantage because of the scale and, you know, it's one the reason why Jeff Bezos is the richest man in the world, worth of $160 -- $170 billion, the market has recognize that.

But it's very intertwined set of issues that have super complicated. It is a big topic for us to Techonomy and I'm glad that Pimm mentioned what we're doing here because we really think that the Techonomy host conference and publishes stuff on our website, Techonomy.com, et cetera.

This whole issue of A.I. has impacted influence in long-term implications and this is simultaneous of the scale of the small number of companies. These are some of the biggest strategic questions that not only business but society has rustled with.

FOX: David Kirkpatrick, to get a little bit more in the weeds because Amazon and the Amazon factor always in the background when it comes to any kind of commercial enterprise now whether it's web services, you described or retail and indeed even the healthcare initiative, what do you believe will be the next industry to be disrupted by Amazon?

KIRKPATRICK: One that I would be pretty seriously expecting is banking. They've got -- and I would say, probably they've got their eyes on insurance as well. I mean, the healthcare thing is still very nascent but they did hire a very immanent healthcare writer and research doctor to work them and at JPMorgan Chase and Berkshire Hathaway on a kind of overall sort of employee oriented project to begin with --

FOX: Right. But do you think insurance and banking, the finance industry?

KIRKPATRICK: Oh, yeah. I mean, look, think of how much banking inspiration Amazon must already had given the scale of commerce that is being concentrated through its platform. You know, it's getting enormous influence. I mean, certainly it offers credit card services are at various sorts and partnership with others now.

ABRAMOWICZ: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: And that's just the beginning. You know, the economy is going digital. So the digital dominant companies are going to have an advantage in almost every industry.

ABRAMOWICZ: But don't think want to avoid the regulation, the oversight that comes along with paying a bank?

KIRKPATRICK: Maybe. Maybe not. I mean, I think Amazon and Jeff Bezos is -- this is one thing he does share with Elon Musk is fearlessness and a willingness to confront unexpected, you know, obstacles and just sort of power through. I don't think that a fear of banking regulation would stop Amazon what the insight that they really wanted to get into that.

I think what would stop and potentially is the fear of antitrust or some kind of new regulatory oversight that they're disparate to avoid but again, the conventional antitrust doesn't even really apply because Amazon tacticals (ph) are in so many industry simultaneously that they're gaining additional scale without actually dominating anyone industry.

I mean, they do dominate online retails so that we could say, if you design as an industry and itself but it isn't retail, it's just the online portion of retail. So I don't think they wouldn't a treat to banks of the outset. It would be after they'd taken advantage of all their other scale advantages that they begin to post a threat.

It's also, think about the fact in their healthcare they are partnering with JPMorgan Chase.

FOX: Indeed.

KIRKPATRICK: Right? What about that?

FOX: Yes, never of the information that they can put together with the joint venture with JPMorgan Chase.

Much appreciated, David Kirkpatrick, he is the Chief Executive and the Founder of Techonomy, also the author of the book, the "Facebook Effect."

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5SG0-79G1-JDPT-T3NT-00000-00DAVID KOSTIN, CHIEF U.S. EQUITY STRATEGIST, GOLDMAN SACHS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION2018-05-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:57ZLexisNexisDAVID KOSTIN, CHIEF U.S. EQUITY STRATEGIST, GOLDMAN SACHS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TELEVISION

May 31, 2018

NEWS PROGRAM

DAVID KOSTIN, CHIEF U.S. EQUITY STRATEGIST, GOLDMAN SACHS

FERRO: Joining us around the table David Kostin, Goldman Sachs Chief U.S. Equity Strategist, George Rusnak, Wells Fargo Investment Institute Co-head of Fixed Income, and Gina Martin Adams of Bloomberg Intelligence Chief Equity Strategist. Guys, great to have you with me around the table.

David, let's begin with you. What are you telling clients about the situation as it unfolds and is it something that we should be worried about?

KOSTIN: Well it's clearly an issue. It's clear risk to margins and in the cost. So the message we've been discussing with clients has been focused on some of the fundamentals that are more domestically facing. And so, let's look at financials which is an area that is most affected by deregulation and some lower taxes and the upcoming CCAR results which are likely to be really sometime in late June. So that's one area to focus on.

And then, focus on companies that are driving their top line sales and the argument behind that is it's less affected by some of the higher input costs that are likely to emanate as a result of the some of the tariffs.

FERRO: There are two points there, let's deal with the first one.

KOSTIN: OK.

FERRO: On the financials, it feels like a shifted domestic kind of story and away from international Gina, are you hearing much more of that thing as well?

ADAMS: Oh absolutely and I think it's playing out on the data with small have index making new highs. The micro caps continuing to make new highs. The S&P is sort of frustratingly stuck in this range. And part of the reason probably is because the dollar is rallying and marks or to some non-domestic risks.

I think really interestingly, you've got this really strong rally in small-cap financials does not being confirmed in the large cap financials. Does that ultimately mean that large cap needs to catch up? They are pretty domestically focused as well or does large cap continue to live because they do have a decent amount of exposure overseas. They do have flow top line growth --

FERRO: Yes.

MARTIN ADAMS: -- as opposed to some of the other components in the index and where can we get that big (move) in large caps financial that's a big question mark for them.

KOSTIN: So you've seen some small-cap banks that had loan growth now running up almost 8 percent?

MARTIN: Right.

KOSTIN: --from the data, which is just one of the key drivers. As well as the ability companies return cash to share this to dividends and buybacks and we hear that in about within the month, by the end of June. We're expecting something in the vicinity of 20 percent incremental dividends and buybacks that will be a key driver. And that will effects of small caps as you indicated as well as large caps.

MALE: Just to jump in, very quickly and bring you some comments from the President of the United States, Donald Trump speaks right now. Let's take and listen.

(BREAK)

FERRO: The President of the United States there discussing an upcoming meeting potentially with the North Korean leader that could happen at some point potentially in the next month or so. And just another brick in a wall of worries, David Kostin, not just trade, the foreign policy as well, usually, we climb that wall of worry.

KOSTIN: Right.

FERRO: And the last week or so been battering into it like this, why?

KOSTIN: Well, the answer there is now variety of outcomes that may or they may or made in that environment, whether the shift is what's happening with corporate earnings and some of the fundamentals?

FERRO: Yes.

KOSTIN: What are companies doing? You see CEO confidence remains very high. Consumer confidence 77 percent economy also indicating it's high levels, one of the highest in the number of years, small business optimism also very high.

So all these indications of confidence are more fundamentally rooted, so there's a lot of geopolitical issues clearly a risk out there. Not clear how you want to invest along that basis.

FERRO: So one fundamental question I guess for you that you've been exploring, David, is whether earnings expansion can offset evaluation contraction. Candid, what's the base case for Goldman?

KOSTIN: I think the base case is you have earnings growth, which is led by economic expansion. But you don't get an evaluation increase. And so we have a evaluation that's high, where somewhere in the 80th, 90th percentile spending on a day of historical evaluations or a high level of equity evaluations.

And so it's really earnings driven looking at the 2019, we really can't look at 2018 because you had this big tailwind from tax lifting the level of profits. And so with the growth rate and profits is really looking into 2019 and looking around probably five percent is the trajectory of growth. That's the type of return we are looking at in the next -- from now to the end of the year.

(BREAK)

FERRO: And, David, that was the one with other concerns, it was rates.

KOSTIN: Right

FERRO: And for you guys, is the danger zone still the four percent, we're someway of it?

KOSTIN: I think got two issues, speed and level.

FERRO: Yes.

KOSTIN: Speed, we're looking at something as a tipping point vicinity 20 to 30 basis point increase in 10 year bond yields within a month. That swiftness of an increase in rates would be of concern in the equity market. Lower, more gentle rise, a lower speed of increase would be less concerning. And from a level point of view, it's something in the vicinity of 375 to four percent on 10 year US treasury yields that would be a build head wind for equity returns.

(BREAK)

FERRO: David, just a final word on that.

KOSTIN: Well, when you think about where you find the earnings growth, the fastest revenue growth which is driving earnings growth, those companies have definitely been outperforming, that's a place to focus on. And it's interesting those are stocks that mutual fund financers are underweight.

Some of the large cap glamour stocks, think about Amazon, Apple, think of Microsoft, Facebook, these companies are underweight in portfolios, despite the fact that expectation is something in the vicinity of 20 plus percent revenue growth which is five times faster than the rest of the market and you have margins that are twice as high and financer actually underweight this visions despite that the dynamic.

It's a way to combat the idea of -- in our forecast is that you have higher bond yields as you need to have better revenue growth and earning growth.

FERRO: David Kostin, of Goldman Sachs, would you please decide it's going to be sticking with us along George Rusnak of Wells Fargo Investment Institute and Gina Martin Adams, our Bloomberg Intelligence.

(BREAK)

FERRO: And still with me, David Kostin of Goldman Sachs, George Rusnak of Wells Fargo Investment Institute, and Gina Martin Adams, Bloomberg Intelligence.

(BREAK)

FERRO: Flows and flows, with the story of last year that explain the effects dynamic. Euro dollar picking up, people wanted to buy Europe, EM picking up people want to do by EM. David, we touched on this and I want to build on it with you. You guys have been looking at a basket of stocks that have high revenue growth in the United States.

KOSTIN: Correct.

FERRO: The Goldman basket which has performed really, really well, and I just wonder whether that's going to develop to be a bigger theme this year. Forget about Euro, forget about (EM) there is some really good growth here in the United States.

KOSTIN: So you definitely have better growth, it's more durable, it's more visible. And from a corporate perspective, if you are worried about and we're concerned about higher input cost potentially, from a labor point view, from a capital perspective in terms of higher interest rates, and a materials perspective, in terms of tariffs potential can potentially imposed, all of those are pressures on margins.

And so, the only combatant you have against that is sales growth. Where are the companies with the best revenue growth? That's the intuition behind focusing on these companies and they're across every -- within every sector, those are the companies that are is comprised of those the companies that have the best top line sales

MALE: And was it --

KOSTIN: Was a Bloomberg ticker and you can pull up people trade it.

(BREAK)

FERRO: If you listen to a program like this over the last year, you would think that tech was really crowded, a big consensus trade and whenever it gets on this program, just so have you understand, typically my producers asked them, what is your contrarian trade? What is your added consensus called?

And David Kostin replies were relative to what and record to mutual funds, to your point, somebody is big tech mantis (ph) contrarian. Walk me through that because to some of our view is that's going to stand quite foreign.

KOSTIN: So the, I call glamour stocks, your Amazon, your Microsoft, Facebook, Apple, those companies, the perception is everyone owns those stocks. And that is not supported by the data.

We look through almost to $2 trillion of holdings, the individual funds, compared within their different benchmarks, core growth value, they are those fundamentals are generally underweight those facts, persistently, consistently.

And that is in here that was indicating. We found at odds with the fact that such significant premium growth in revenues, and you have much higher margins. And that would be in my view supportive of to do that performance of some of those companies.

And why that's the case is a perception that they are -- everyone owns them. And be they're concerned about potential deregulation or regulation and some of the --

FERRO: Yes.

KOSTIN: -- monopolistic discussion that takes place in regulations in Washington or Europe, so those of you at risks, but the driving revenues is I think about the key.

So that's the first observation is where have viewed it's a different or variant from consensus and on the hedge fund side -- hedge fund have a very small position in finances. They have a less than 10 percent of the net exposure, when you net out the gross and along the shores, about 10 percent, as about 15 percent index.

Obviously, a hedge fund is not a benchmark oriented they are total return oriented. And we see what's catalyst in this market where it's been sort of chopping, move around side ways. You have in the next three weeks, you have the CCAR results. The stress test results and the fed will be, in our view likely to be approving, authorizing a return of dividends and buybacks for the next 12 months and increase about 20 percent.

And that is we saw that last year. Trading environment, when you had the CCAR results came out, bank stocks rallied significantly on the back of a significant increase in the planned capital return holders, and that I think is a catalyst. So we are divergent from consensus or the broad view on the hedge fund side and on the mutual fund side

FERRO: David Kostin great to catch up with up, with Goldman Sachs. So let's stay longer with this next time, I know you're going to go. David Kostin, great to have you with us.

(BREAK)

END

And so, let's look at financials which is an area that is most affected by deregulation and some lower taxes and the upcoming CCAR results which are likely to be really sometime in late June. So that's one area to focus on.

And then, focus on companies that are driving their top line sales and the argument behind that is it's less affected by some of the higher input costs that are likely to emanate as a result of the some of the tariffs.

FERRO: There are two points there, let's deal with the first one.

KOSTIN: OK.

The S&P is sort of frustratingly stuck in this range. And part of the reason probably is because the dollar is rallying and marks or to some non-domestic risks.

I think really interestingly, you've got this really strong rally in small- cap financials does not being confirmed in the large cap financials. Does that ultimately mean that large cap needs to catch up? They are pretty domestically focused as well or does large cap continue to live because they do have a decent amount of exposure overseas. They do have flow top line growth --

FERRO: Yes.

MARTIN ADAMS: -- as opposed to some of the other components in the index and where can we get that big (move) in large caps financial that's a big question mark for them.

KOSTIN: So you've seen some small-cap banks that had loan growth now running up almost 8 percent?

MARTIN: Right.

KOSTIN: --from the data, which is just one of the key drivers. As well as the ability companies return cash to share this to dividends and buybacks and we hear that in about within the month, by the end of June. We're expecting something in the vicinity of 20 percent incremental dividends and buybacks that will be a key driver. And that will effects of small caps as you indicated as well as large caps.

MALE: Just to jump in, very quickly and bring you some comments from the President of the United States, Donald Trump speaks right now. Let's take and listen.

(BREAK)

FERRO: The President of the United States there discussing an upcoming meeting potentially with the North Korean leader that could happen at some point potentially in the next month or so. That's the type of return we are looking at in the next -- from now to the end of the year.

FERRO: David Kostin great to catch up with up, with Goldman Sachs. So let's stay longer with this next time, I know you're going to go. David Kostin, great to have you with us.

And from a level point of view, it's something in the vicinity of 375 to four percent on 10 year US treasury yields that would be a build head wind for equity returns.

(BREAK)

FERRO: David, just a final word on that.

KOSTIN: Well, when you think about where you find the earnings growth, the fastest revenue growth which is driving earnings growth, those companies have definitely been outperforming, that's a place to focus on. And it's interesting those are stocks that mutual fund financers are underweight.

Some of the large cap glamour stocks, think about Amazon, Apple, think of Microsoft, Facebook, these companies are underweight in portfolios, despite the fact that expectation is something in the vicinity of 20 plus percent revenue growth which is five times faster than the rest of the market and you have margins that are twice as high and financer actually underweight this visions despite that the dynamic.

It's a way to combat the idea of -- in our forecast is that you have higher bond yields as you need to have better revenue growth and earning growth.

FERRO: David Kostin, of Goldman Sachs, would you please decide it's going to be sticking with us along George Rusnak of Wells Fargo Investment Institute and Gina Martin Adams, our Bloomberg Intelligence.

(BREAK)

FERRO: And still with me, David Kostin of Goldman Sachs, George Rusnak of Wells Fargo Investment Institute, and Gina Martin Adams, Bloomberg Intelligence.

(BREAK)

FERRO: Flows and flows, with the story of last year that explain the effects dynamic. Euro dollar picking up, people wanted to buy Europe, EM picking up people want to do by EM. David, we touched on this and I want to build on it with you. You guys have been looking at a basket of stocks that have high revenue growth in the United States.

KOSTIN: Correct.

KOSTIN: So you definitely have better growth, it's more durable, it's more visible. And from a corporate perspective, if you are worried about and we're concerned about higher input cost potentially, from a labor point view, from a capital perspective in terms of higher interest rates, and a materials perspective, in terms of tariffs potential can potentially imposed, all of those are pressures on margins.

And so, the only combatant you have against that is sales growth. Where are the companies with the best revenue growth? That's the intuition behind focusing on these companies and they're across every -- within every sector, those are the companies that are is comprised of those the companies that have the best top line sales

KOSTIN: Was a Bloomberg ticker and you can pull up people trade it.

(BREAK)

FERRO: If you listen to a program like this over the last year, you would think that tech was really crowded, a big consensus trade and whenever it gets on this program, just so have you understand, typically my producers asked them, what is your contrarian trade? What is your added consensus called?

And David Kostin replies were relative to what and record to mutual funds, to your point, somebody is big tech mantis (ph) contrarian. Walk me through that because to some of our view is that's going to stand quite foreign.

KOSTIN: So the, I call glamour stocks, your Amazon, your Microsoft, Facebook, Apple, those companies, the perception is everyone owns those stocks. And that is not supported by the data.

We look through almost to $2 trillion of holdings, the individual funds, compared within their different benchmarks, core growth value, they are those fundamentals are generally underweight those facts, persistently, consistently.

And that is in here that was indicating. We found at odds with the fact that such significant premium growth in revenues, and you have much higher margins. And that would be in my view supportive of to do that performance of some of those companies.

And why that's the case is a perception that they are -- everyone owns them. And be they're concerned about potential deregulation or regulation and some of the --

FERRO: Yes.

KOSTIN: -- monopolistic discussion that takes place in regulations in Washington or Europe, so those of you at risks, but the driving revenues is I think about the key.

So that's the first observation is where have viewed it's a different or variant from consensus and on the hedge fund side -- hedge fund have a very small position in finances. They have a less than 10 percent of the net exposure, when you net out the gross and along the shores, about 10 percent, as about 15 percent index.

Obviously, a hedge fund is not a benchmark oriented they are total return oriented. And we see what's catalyst in this market where it's been sort of chopping, move around side ways. You have in the next three weeks, you have the CCAR results. The stress test results and the fed will be, in our view likely to be approving, authorizing a return of dividends and buybacks for the next 12 months and increase about 20 percent.

And that is we saw that last year. Trading environment, when you had the CCAR results came out, bank stocks rallied significantly on the back of a significant increase in the planned capital return holders, and that I think is a catalyst. So we are divergent from consensus or the broad view on the hedge fund side and on the mutual fund side

FERRO: David Kostin great to catch up with up, with Goldman Sachs. So let's stay longer with this next time, I know you're going to go. David Kostin, great to have you with us.

(BREAK)

David Kostin discusses politics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID KOSTIN, CHIEF U.S. EQUITY STRATEGIST, GOLDMAN SACHS, IS INTERVIEWED ON BB TV

MAY 31, 2018

SPEAKERS: DAVID KOSTIN, CHIEF U.S. EQUITY STRATEGIST, GOLDMAN SACHS

GINA MARTIN ADAMS, BLOOMBERG NEWS

JONATHAN FERRO, BLOOMBERG NEWS

Guys, great to have you with me around the table.

David, let's begin with you. What are you telling clients about the situation as it unfolds and is it something that we should be worried about?

DAVID KOSTIN, CHIEF U.S. EQUITY STRATEGIST, GOLDMAN SACHS: Well it's clearly an issue. It's clear risk to margins and in the cost. So the message we've been discussing with clients has been focused on some of the fundamentals that are more domestically facing. And so, let's look at financials which is an area that is most affected by deregulation and some lower taxes and the upcoming CCAR results which are likely to be really sometime in late June. So that's one area to focus on.

And then, focus on companies that are driving their top line sales and the argument behind that is it's less affected by some of the higher input costs that are likely to emanate as a result of the some of the tariffs.

FERRO: There are two points there, let's deal with the first one.

KOSTIN: OK.

FERRO: On the financials, it feels like a shifted domestic kind of story and away from international Gina, are you hearing much more of that thing as well?

GINA MARTIN ADAMS, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Oh absolutely and I think it's playing out on the data with small have index making new highs. The micro caps continuing to make new highs. The S&P is sort of frustratingly stuck in this range. And part of the reason probably is because the dollar is rallying and marks or to some non-domestic risks.

I think really interestingly, you've got this really strong rally in small- cap financials does not being confirmed in the large cap financials. Does that ultimately mean that large cap needs to catch up? They are pretty domestically focused as well or does large cap continue to live because they do have a decent amount of exposure overseas. They do have flow top line growth --

FERRO: Yes.

MARTIN ADAMS: -- as opposed to some of the other components in the index and where can we get that big (move) in large caps financial that's a big question mark for them.

KOSTIN: So you've seen some small-cap banks that had loan growth now running up almost 8 percent?

MARTIN: Right.

KOSTIN: --from the data, which is just one of the key drivers. As well as the ability companies return cash to share this to dividends and buybacks and we hear that in about within the month, by the end of June. We're expecting something in the vicinity of 20 percent incremental dividends and buybacks that will be a key driver. And that will effects of small caps as you indicated as well as large caps.

MALE: Just to jump in, very quickly and bring you some comments from the President of the United States, Donald Trump speaks right now. Let's take and listen.

(BREAK)

FERRO: The President of the United States there discussing an upcoming meeting potentially with the North Korean leader that could happen at some point potentially in the next month or so. And just another brick in a wall of worries, David Kostin, not just trade, the foreign policy as well, usually, we climb that wall of worry.

KOSTIN: Right.

FERRO: And the last week or so been battering into it like this, why?

KOSTIN: Well, the answer there is now variety of outcomes that may or they may or made in that environment, whether the shift is what's happening with corporate earnings and some of the fundamentals?

FERRO: Yes.

KOSTIN: What are companies doing? You see CEO confidence remains very high. Consumer confidence 77 percent economy also indicating it's high levels, one of the highest in the number of years, small business optimism also very high.

So all these indications of confidence are more fundamentally rooted, so there's a lot of geopolitical issues clearly a risk out there. Not clear how you want to invest along that basis.

FERRO: So one fundamental question I guess for you that you've been exploring, David, is whether earnings expansion can offset evaluation contraction. Candid, what's the base case for Goldman?

KOSTIN: I think the base case is you have earnings growth, which is led by economic expansion. But you don't get an evaluation increase. And so we have a evaluation that's high, where somewhere in the 80th, 90th percentile spending on a day of historical evaluations or a high level of equity evaluations.

And so it's really earnings driven looking at the 2019, we really can't look at 2018 because you had this big tailwind from tax lifting the level of profits. And so with the growth rate and profits is really looking into 2019 and looking around probably five percent is the trajectory of growth. That's the type of return we are looking at in the next -- from now to the end of the year.

(BREAK)

FERRO: And, David, that was the one with other concerns, it was rates.

KOSTIN: Right

FERRO: And for you guys, is the danger zone still the four percent, we're someway of it?

KOSTIN: I think got two issues, speed and level.

FERRO: Yes.

KOSTIN: Speed, we're looking at something as a tipping point vicinity 20 to 30 basis point increase in 10 year bond yields within a month. That swiftness of an increase in rates would be of concern in the equity market. Lower, more gentle rise, a lower speed of increase would be less concerning. And from a level point of view, it's something in the vicinity of 375 to four percent on 10 year US treasury yields that would be a build head wind for equity returns.

(BREAK)

FERRO: David, just a final word on that.

Some of the large cap glamour stocks, think about Amazon, Apple, think of Microsoft, Facebook, these companies are underweight in portfolios, despite the fact that expectation is something in the vicinity of 20 plus percent revenue growth which is five times faster than the rest of the market and you have margins that are twice as high and financer actually underweight this visions despite that the dynamic.

It's a way to combat the idea of -- in our forecast is that you have higher bond yields as you need to have better revenue growth and earning growth.

FERRO: David Kostin, of Goldman Sachs, would you please decide it's going to be sticking with us along George Rusnak of Wells Fargo Investment Institute and Gina Martin Adams, our Bloomberg Intelligence.

(BREAK)

FERRO: And still with me, David Kostin of Goldman Sachs, George Rusnak of Wells Fargo Investment Institute, and Gina Martin Adams, Bloomberg Intelligence.

(BREAK)

FERRO: Flows and flows, with the story of last year that explain the effects dynamic. Euro dollar picking up, people wanted to buy Europe, EM picking up people want to do by EM. David, we touched on this and I want to build on it with you. You guys have been looking at a basket of stocks that have high revenue growth in the United States.

KOSTIN: Correct.

FERRO: The Goldman basket which has performed really, really well, and I just wonder whether that's going to develop to be a bigger theme this year. Forget about Euro, forget about (EM) there is some really good growth here in the United States.

KOSTIN: So you definitely have better growth, it's more durable, it's more visible. And from a corporate perspective, if you are worried about and we're concerned about higher input cost potentially, from a labor point view, from a capital perspective in terms of higher interest rates, and a materials perspective, in terms of tariffs potential can potentially imposed, all of those are pressures on margins.

And so, the only combatant you have against that is sales growth. Where are the companies with the best revenue growth? That's the intuition behind focusing on these companies and they're across every -- within every sector, those are the companies that are is comprised of those the companies that have the best top line sales

KOSTIN: Was a Bloomberg ticker and you can pull up people trade it.

(BREAK)

FERRO: If you listen to a program like this over the last year, you would think that tech was really crowded, a big consensus trade and whenever it gets on this program, just so have you understand, typically my producers asked them, what is your contrarian trade? What is your added consensus called?

And David Kostin replies were relative to what and record to mutual funds, to your point, somebody is big tech mantis (ph) contrarian. Walk me through that because to some of our view is that's going to stand quite foreign.

KOSTIN: So the, I call glamour stocks, your Amazon, your Microsoft, Facebook, Apple, those companies, the perception is everyone owns those stocks. And that is not supported by the data.

We look through almost to $2 trillion of holdings, the individual funds, compared within their different benchmarks, core growth value, they are those fundamentals are generally underweight those facts, persistently, consistently.

And that is in here that was indicating. We found at odds with the fact that such significant premium growth in revenues, and you have much higher margins. And that would be in my view supportive of to do that performance of some of those companies.

And why that's the case is a perception that they are -- everyone owns them. And be they're concerned about potential deregulation or regulation and some of the --

FERRO: Yes.

KOSTIN: -- monopolistic discussion that takes place in regulations in Washington or Europe, so those of you at risks, but the driving revenues is I think about the key.

So that's the first observation is where have viewed it's a different or variant from consensus and on the hedge fund side -- hedge fund have a very small position in finances. They have a less than 10 percent of the net exposure, when you net out the gross and along the shores, about 10 percent, as about 15 percent index.

Obviously, a hedge fund is not a benchmark oriented they are total return oriented. And we see what's catalyst in this market where it's been sort of chopping, move around side ways. You have in the next three weeks, you have the CCAR results. The stress test results and the fed will be, in our view likely to be approving, authorizing a return of dividends and buybacks for the next 12 months and increase about 20 percent.

And that is we saw that last year. Trading environment, when you had the CCAR results came out, bank stocks rallied significantly on the back of a significant increase in the planned capital return holders, and that I think is a catalyst. So we are divergent from consensus or the broad view on the hedge fund side and on the mutual fund side

FERRO: David Kostin great to catch up with up, with Goldman Sachs. So let's stay longer with this next time, I know you're going to go. David Kostin, great to have you with us.

(BREAK)

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

FERRO: David, just a final word on that.

Some of the large cap glamour stocks, think about Amazon, Apple, think of Microsoft, Facebook, these companies are underweight in portfolios, despite the fact that expectation is something in the vicinity of 20 plus percent revenue growth which is five times faster than the rest of the market and you have margins that are twice as high and financer actually underweight this visions despite that the dynamic.

It's a way to combat the idea of -- in our forecast is that you have higher bond yields as you need to have better revenue growth and earning growth.

FERRO: David Kostin, of Goldman Sachs, would you please decide it's going to be sticking with us along George Rusnak of Wells Fargo Investment Institute and Gina Martin Adams, our Bloomberg Intelligence.

(BREAK)

FERRO: And still with me, David Kostin of Goldman Sachs, George Rusnak of Wells Fargo Investment Institute, and Gina Martin Adams, Bloomberg Intelligence.

(BREAK)

FERRO: Flows and flows, with the story of last year that explain the effects dynamic. Euro dollar picking up, people wanted to buy Europe, EM picking up people want to do by EM. David, we touched on this and I want to build on it with you. You guys have been looking at a basket of stocks that have high revenue growth in the United States.

KOSTIN: Correct.

FERRO: The Goldman basket which has performed really, really well, and I just wonder whether that's going to develop to be a bigger theme this year. Forget about Euro, forget about (EM) there is some really good growth here in the United States.

KOSTIN: So you definitely have better growth, it's more durable, it's more visible. And from a corporate perspective, if you are worried about and we're concerned about higher input cost potentially, from a labor point view, from a capital perspective in terms of higher interest rates, and a materials perspective, in terms of tariffs potential can potentially imposed, all of those are pressures on margins.

And so, the only combatant you have against that is sales growth. Where are the companies with the best revenue growth? That's the intuition behind focusing on these companies and they're across every -- within every sector, those are the companies that are is comprised of those the companies that have the best top line sales

MALE: And was it --

KOSTIN: Was a Bloomberg ticker and you can pull up people trade it.

(BREAK)

FERRO: If you listen to a program like this over the last year, you would think that tech was really crowded, a big consensus trade and whenever it gets on this program, just so have you understand, typically my producers asked them, what is your contrarian trade? What is your added consensus called?

And David Kostin replies were relative to what and record to mutual funds, to your point, somebody is big tech mantis (ph) contrarian. Walk me through that because to some of our view is that's going to stand quite foreign.

KOSTIN: So the, I call glamour stocks, your Amazon, your Microsoft, Facebook, Apple, those companies, the perception is everyone owns those stocks. And that is not supported by the data.

We look through almost to $2 trillion of holdings, the individual funds, compared within their different benchmarks, core growth value, they are those fundamentals are generally underweight those facts, persistently, consistently.

And that is in here that was indicating. We found at odds with the fact that such significant premium growth in revenues, and you have much higher margins. And that would be in my view supportive of to do that performance of some of those companies.

And why that's the case is a perception that they are -- everyone owns them. And be they're concerned about potential deregulation or regulation and some of the --

FERRO: Yes.

KOSTIN: -- monopolistic discussion that takes place in regulations in Washington or Europe, so those of you at risks, but the driving revenues is I think about the key.

So that's the first observation is where have viewed it's a different or variant from consensus and on the hedge fund side -- hedge fund have a very small position in finances. They have a less than 10 percent of the net exposure, when you net out the gross and along the shores, about 10 percent, as about 15 percent index.

Obviously, a hedge fund is not a benchmark oriented they are total return oriented. And we see what's catalyst in this market where it's been sort of chopping, move around side ways. You have in the next three weeks, you have the CCAR results. The stress test results and the fed will be, in our view likely to be approving, authorizing a return of dividends and buybacks for the next 12 months and increase about 20 percent.

And that is we saw that last year. Trading environment, when you had the CCAR results came out, bank stocks rallied significantly on the back of a significant increase in the planned capital return holders, and that I think is a catalyst. So we are divergent from consensus or the broad view on the hedge fund side and on the mutual fund side

FERRO: David Kostin great to catch up with up, with Goldman Sachs. So let's stay longer with this next time, I know you're going to go. David Kostin, great to have you with us.

(BREAK)

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WTV-YVV1-DY91-K32D-00000-00David Olive: Facebook is too powerful. It's time to break it up2019-08-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:57ZLexisNexisSTAR BUSINESS JOURNALPg. 0David Olive: Facebook is too powerful. It's time to break it upDavid Olive

Facebook Inc. needs to be broken up.

The company represents too much power in a single entity - indeed, in a single person.

Facebook co-founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg controls about 60 per cent of Facebook's voting shares. The firm's directors are advisers to Zuckerberg, 35, not genuine overseers.

Facebook and its Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp platforms have a combined 6.2 billion users. That's 81 per cent of humanity - a big number even accounting for duplication.

Facebook's share of the global market in social networking exceeds 80 per cent.

With 2018 revenues of $55 billion, Facebook leaves little room for rivals. It has been eight years since anyone has dared attempt a major social-media startup. (All figures in U.S. dollars.)

Facebook did not achieve its dominance through innovation. It used the expedient of 72 takeovers costing a total of $23.4 billion to purchase the innovations of others.

With its commanding market share, Facebook is immensely profitable. Facebook's 2018 profit margin was 39.6 per cent. The number for Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc. that year was 1.3 per cent.

With global regulators and heads of government impatient for reform at the internet giants, after years of ineffective fines, Facebook's critics are stepping up the pressure on Zuckerberg's firm.

Earlier this month, the U.S. Department of Justice announced America's most aggressive investigation to date into monopolist practices at internet firms.

But that effort is likely to fail.

The U.S. is expected to put several internet companies under the microscope, including Facebook, Google Inc. (owner of YouTube, a social-media video platform), Amazon.com Inc., Apple Inc. and Twitter Inc.

Yet Facebook, Google and Twitter are not guilty of consumer price-gouging, the narrow U.S. definition of monopolistic abuse that guides most antitrust prosecutions. Their services are free.

And Amazon and Apple are not monopolies. Walmart Inc. alone has twice the revenues of Amazon. And in smartphones, Apple's chief source of revenues, the company trails Samsung Electronics Co. and Huawei Technologies Inc. in market share.

The most effective remedy to Big Tech's market abuses is to focus on one alleged miscreant, Facebook, a near-monopoly with a history of dubious practices. If charges against Facebook resulted in a conviction, the firm would be broken up.

Drastic as that might seem, there are tougher measures. "The most effective path to reform would be to shut down the platforms at least temporarily," Roger McNamee, a U.S. venture capitalist and early investor in Facebook, told a Canadian House of Commons committee in May.

"Companies with responsible business models will emerge overnight to fill the void."

And other Big Tech firms might embrace reform to avoid Facebook's fate.

Facebook has too much power

"Mark [Zuckerberg]'s influence is staggering, far beyond that of anyone else in the private sector or in government," Facebook co-founder Chris R. Hughes wrote in a New York Times essay in May. Hughes has called for the breakup of Facebook.

"He has created a Leviathan that crowds out entrepreneurship and restricts consumer choice," Hughes wrote.

Facebook uses the vast trove of user data it collects to attract advertisers. Any future uses for that data will ultimately be determined by Zuckerberg.

Facebook provided the personal data of 87 million Facebook users, including about 620,000 Canadians, to British political consultancy Cambridge Analytica. The data was used to manipulate the outcome of the 2016 Brexit referendum and U.S. presidential election later that year.

The U.S. fined Facebook $5 billion this month for misleading users about the use of their data in that case. The fine equals one-quarter of Facebook's 2018 profits - a cost of doing business.

It was for Zuckerberg, not New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, to decide to take down the live-streaming video of two mosque massacres in Christchurch on March 15. By that point, the video had been viewed, according to Facebook, about 4,000 times.

The decision not to act on pleas that live-streaming videos be pre-screened before they are posted is Zuckerberg's. (Although YouTube has the same policy.)

In late 2017, Zuckerberg decided to shut down Facebook accounts of Myanmar users whom he felt were inciting genocide. But ahead of this year's general election in India, Zuckerberg chose not to shut down WhatsApp accounts of extremists spreading hate messages before the vote.

Facebook is effectively a utility, but it's regulated by Zuckerberg. There's nothing to stop Zuckerberg from denying service in Montreal, Germany or Western Australia. His decisions are self-interested, and he has admitted to mistakes.

What would the breakup look like?

Facebook would simply spin off its huge Instagram, WhatsApp and Messenger platforms, and possibly its News Feed as well. They would become stand-alone, independent companies competing with each other and their former parent.

With the exception of the News Feed, a notorious disseminator of fake news and conspiracy theories, those platforms and services are acquisitions that can be unwound with relative ease.

Zuckerberg is now trying to integrate them to make a breakup more difficult.

The antitrust settlement would include a five-year moratorium on acquisitions by Facebook, giving established rivals and startups the time to effectively compete with it.

Action against Facebook would be accompanied by a new regulatory agency to better protect the privacy of all internet users. The new U.S. agency, which soon would have counterparts in other jurisdictions, could be modelled on the EU's landmark General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

The GDPR guarantees users a minimum of privacy protection. It would have to be upgraded to give users maximum control of their data, full disclosure of what is being collected, and an effortless user ability to remove or correct personal data.

A breakup would lead to more innovation online

Chief among the benefits is maximum user control over their personal information. And social-media users would have greater choice. They could pay for sites with no advertising, or pick the platform with the highest privacy standards. Competing news feeds, as apps, could compete on accuracy, price and global scope or hyperlocal content.

And the new regulator, in addition to preventing market abuses, would also create guidelines for acceptable speech, drawn from existing hate-speech laws in most Western countries.

In voluntarily dismantling enterprises, corporate dealmakers speak of "unlocking" shareholder value. And that has been the result of most corporate breakups. In the decade following the 1984 breakup of AT&T, the seven successor companies to Ma Bell tripled in shareholder value.

But probably the biggest benefit of a Facebook breakup, and pressure to "unlock" shareholder value at other Big Tech firms, would be its impact in unleashing - or restoring - innovative entrepreneurship.

The 1990s antitrust prosecution of Microsoft Corp. for illegally using its size to crush a pioneering Web browser firm (Netscape) helped keep Bill Gates from taking control of the early internet.

And that cleared the way for thousands of startup internet innovators, including Mark Zuckerberg, whose firm was launched just 14 years ago in his Harvard dorm room.

David Olive is a Toronto-based business columnist for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @TheGrtRecession

The most effective remedy to Big Tech's market abuses is to focus on one alleged miscreant, Facebook, a near-monopoly with a history of dubious practices. If charges against Facebook resulted in a conviction, the firm would be broken up.

Drastic as that might seem, there are tougher measures. "The most effective path to reform would be to shut down the platforms at least temporarily," Roger McNamee, a U.S. venture capitalist and early investor in Facebook, told a Canadian House of Commons committee in May.

"Companies with responsible business models will emerge overnight to fill the void."

And other Big Tech firms might embrace reform to avoid Facebook's fate.

Facebook has too much power

"Mark [Zuckerberg]'s influence is staggering, far beyond that of anyone else in the private sector or in government," Facebook co-founder Chris R. Hughes wrote in a New York Times essay in May. Hughes has called for the breakup of Facebook.

"He has created a Leviathan that crowds out entrepreneurship and restricts consumer choice," Hughes wrote.

Facebook uses the vast trove of user data it collects to attract advertisers. Any future uses for that data will ultimately be determined by Zuckerberg.

Facebook provided the personal data of 87 million Facebook users, including about 620,000 Canadians, to British political consultancy Cambridge Analytica. The data was used to manipulate the outcome of the 2016 Brexit referendum and U.S. presidential election later that year.

The U.S. fined Facebook $5 billion this month for misleading users about the use of their data in that case. The fine equals one-quarter of Facebook's 2018 profits - a cost of doing business.

It was for Zuckerberg, not New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern, to decide to take down the live-streaming video of two mosque massacres in Christchurch on March 15. By that point, the video had been viewed, according to Facebook, about 4,000 times.

The decision not to act on pleas that live-streaming videos be pre-screened before they are posted is Zuckerberg's. (Although YouTube has the same policy.)

In late 2017, Zuckerberg decided to shut down Facebook accounts of Myanmar users whom he felt were inciting genocide. But ahead of this year's general election in India, Zuckerberg chose not to shut down WhatsApp accounts of extremists spreading hate messages before the vote.

Facebook is effectively a utility, but it's regulated by Zuckerberg. There's nothing to stop Zuckerberg from denying service in Montreal, Germany or Western Australia. His decisions are self-interested, and he has admitted to mistakes.

What would the breakup look like?

Facebook would simply spin off its huge Instagram, WhatsApp and Messenger platforms, and possibly its News Feed as well. They would become stand-alone, independent companies competing with each other and their former parent.

With the exception of the News Feed, a notorious disseminator of fake news and conspiracy theories, those platforms and services are acquisitions that can be unwound with relative ease.

Zuckerberg is now trying to integrate them to make a breakup more difficult.

The antitrust settlement would include a five-year moratorium on acquisitions by Facebook, giving established rivals and startups the time to effectively compete with it.

Action against Facebook would be accompanied by a new regulatory agency to better protect the privacy of all internet users. The new U.S. agency, which soon would have counterparts in other jurisdictions, could be modelled on the EU's landmark General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

The GDPR guarantees users a minimum of privacy protection. It would have to be upgraded to give users maximum control of their data, full disclosure of what is being collected, and an effortless user ability to remove or correct personal data.

A breakup would lead to more innovation online

Chief among the benefits is maximum user control over their personal information. And social-media users would have greater choice. They could pay for sites with no advertising, or pick the platform with the highest privacy standards. Competing news feeds, as apps, could compete on accuracy, price and global scope or hyperlocal content.

And the new regulator, in addition to preventing market abuses, would also create guidelines for acceptable speech, drawn from existing hate-speech laws in most Western countries.

In voluntarily dismantling enterprises, corporate dealmakers speak of "unlocking" shareholder value. And that has been the result of most corporate breakups. In the decade following the 1984 breakup of AT&T, the seven successor companies to Ma Bell tripled in shareholder value.

But probably the biggest benefit of a Facebook breakup, and pressure to "unlock" shareholder value at other Big Tech firms, would be its impact in unleashing - or restoring - innovative entrepreneurship.

The 1990s antitrust prosecution of Microsoft Corp. for illegally using its size to crush a pioneering Web browser firm (Netscape) helped keep Bill Gates from taking control of the early internet.

And that cleared the way for thousands of startup internet innovators, including Mark Zuckerberg, whose firm was launched just 14 years ago in his Harvard dorm room.

David Olive is a Toronto-based business columnist for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @TheGrtRecession

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XWY-SD31-JDH1-C3XY-00000-00David Olive: Five business trends to watch in 2020: Why big government will get bigger and wind power will boom2020-01-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:37:57ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 0David Olive: Five business trends to watch in 2020: Why big government will get bigger and wind power will boomDavid Olive

A comeback for Big Government

Popular sentiment swings between antipathy toward government and demand for more state intervention. In recent years, governments in Western economies have been in retreat, afraid of their own shadows. Business has not filled the void. Left to its self-determined course, capitalism has failed to address the crises in climate emergency; income inequality; shortages of affordable housing and of skills; and of deficient transportation and other infrastructure. Business investment has not risen in tandem with burgeoning corporate profits.

Instead, the profits have gone into stock buybacks, executive bonuses and dividends rather than sufficient reinvestment, slowing the pace of innovation. "Warnings that the capital markets aren't functioning properly are everywhere," Mariana Mazzucato, director of the University College London's innovation institute told Fortune in December. In Canada, popular support for pharmacare and the world's first national carbon-pricing system mark a turning point. So does the growing public demand that governments rein in Big Tech and the threats it poses to personal privacy and public safety. But the swing in favour of state involvement will be most pronounced in climate crisis. The Bank of Canada and other central banks are warning with ever greater urgency that the global economic system cannot withstand the unprecedented catastrophes - what Warren Buffett calls "super-cats" - for which humanity must brace. A start this year will be discussions over a new state-supported global backstop for insurers, who face insolvency with the first string of claims arising from massive climate-related property damage events. Climate crisis demands a return to the model of public-private partnership that created the modern computer age, the space missions and the internet era.

Cell-based food

The current plant-based food movement is driven by concerns over healthier diets, animal welfare, and the smaller carbon footprint of plant-based foods than that of livestock. The next step, food derived from the cells of cows and poultry - or "cellular agriculture" - puts protein-rich meat back on the menu with no slaughterhouses and, unlike plant-based food, less use of limited fresh water and other taxes on the land imposed by plant cultivation. Plant-based meat replacements also require extraordinary processing to make them palatable, and the disagreeable taste of first-generation plant-based foods is a stigma the industry is still working to overcome. The 30 or so Canadian and global firms developing "cultivated meat" from animal cells, determined not to make that mistake, won't have their first products to market until 2023. But investment in lab-based meat has ramped up, increasing by 120 per cent globally last year, to $80 million, to supply a market modestly estimated at $514 million by 2030. For Canadian start-up firms in this new realm, including Edmonton's Future Fields and Appleton Meats of Vancouver, the challenge isn't the science, which is well advanced. The obstacle is a lack of venture capital for the costly equipment required in the manufacturing process. A fraction of the billions of dollars Canadians invested in the pot craze would ensure that Canadian scientists and entrepreneurs have a place in what could be the biggest revolution in food production since the advent of crop rotation. Otherwise, the new industry will be gobbled up by the same foreign-based Big Food combines that have long dominated Canadian food consumption.

The rise in renewable energy and the SUV challenge

Fortunately, coal, the dirtiest of all fuels used in electricity production, is projected to drop to 34 per cent of global power sources by decade's end, and be overtaken by renewables such as wind, solar and hydro power, accounting for 42 per cent of global electricity production by 2030. Wind power, once dismissed as an unreliable energy source, is poised to boom in 2020 and beyond. The European Union (EU), world's third-largest economy after the U.S. and China, already looks to wind for two per cent of its power generation. That percentage was recently forecast to rise ninefold by 2040 by the International Energy Agency (IEA), in its annual World Energy Outlook report in December. Companies are not only planning huge offshore wind farms in the North Sea - where energy firms can harvest stronger and steadier winds - but in offshore North America, China, Japan and South Korea, as well. That favourable trend strengthens another, the higher-than-expected adoption rate of all-electric vehicles (EVs), a record two million of which were bought last year. But against that gain for cleaner air is a surge in sport utility vehicle sales (SUVs), now accounting for 42 per cent of passenger-vehicle sales, more than double the rate in 2000. Note to investors: Pay attention to firms like oil giant Suncor Energy Inc. of Calgary that are investing heavily in wind power, wisely hedging its bets against a decline in fossil fuels; and automakers like Nissan, Hyundai and Volkswagen's Audi that lead in the electric SUV race.

A new debate about 5G's implications

The social consequences of fifth-generation (5G) wireless networks will start to come under scrutiny in 2020, as 5G networks roll out in Canada over the next two years. About 10 times faster than current technology, 5G will see data moving at record speed and volume, and promises to connect every digital device, from cars to refrigerators to water-filtration-plant control rooms. The widespread misgivings that have already arisen about massive data collection will become acute. Who will set the rules on what data can be collected, and to what use it can be put? What new cybersecurity threats are we creating? That discussion will intensify this year, as the telcos pursue their goal of connecting everything digital in the country. The new technology has its virtues. As an enabler of low-cost virtual reality (VR), 5G will provide surgeons with detailed images of the patients they are treating, and tell firefighters exactly what they will encounter as they enter a burning structure. With an error rate one-thousandth that of current technology, 5G will be a blessing in "mission critical" applications in health care, manufacturing and transportation networks. And consumers can expect more efficient households, eHealth systems and supply chains in retailing, utilities and public safety, with 5G's ability to connect about one million digital devices per square kilometre. Yet 5G also raises the spectre of a surveillance society, with ubiquitous sensors tracking our every move. We can't allow 5G to proceed as social media have, an unregulated phenomenon whose downside caught us unprepared.

Business loses an excuse for underinvesting in Canada

Canadian businesses are expected to continue underinvesting in their enterprises in 2020, according to the Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC), worsening a trend that has seen Canadian corporate investment drop by about 20 per cent since the oil-price slump of 2014. Canada touts itself as an emerging high-tech superpower, given all the global firms that have set up their artificial intelligence (AI) workshops in Canada. But that's foreign capital. By contrast, Canadian firms have cut investment in intellectual property development by $532,000 per worker over the past decade, and reduced their total capex by $1,446 per worker. No wonder Canadian GDP per capita - that is, standard of living - has actually dropped three per cent from 2010 levels, a lost decade that contrasts with the 35 per cent surge in U.S. GDP per capita in that period. Business-lobby whining about unfavourable Canadian tax and regulatory conditions is nonsensical. Even before Ottawa gave business a whopping additional tax break in accelerated depreciation on capital investments, Canada was already in the highest ranks of countries for ease of doing business. And offshore investors facing those same "unfavourable" Canadian conditions poured $65.8 billion into Canadian investments last year, close to the record set before the oil-price collapse. The stark reality is that Canadian business has less faith in Canada than outsiders. With the likely ebbing this year of global trade tensions that Canadian business also cites for lack of enterprise, we'll see this year if judicious caution or unwarranted trepidation is the real issue here.

David Olive is a Toronto-based business columnist for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @TheGrtRecession

We can't allow 5G to proceed as social media have, an unregulated phenomenon whose downside caught us unprepared.

Business loses an excuse for underinvesting in Canada

Canadian businesses are expected to continue underinvesting in their enterprises in 2020, according to the Business Development Bank of Canada (BDC), worsening a trend that has seen Canadian corporate investment drop by about 20 per cent since the oil-price slump of 2014. Canada touts itself as an emerging high-tech superpower, given all the global firms that have set up their artificial intelligence (AI) workshops in Canada. But that's foreign capital. By contrast, Canadian firms have cut investment in intellectual property development by $532,000 per worker over the past decade, and reduced their total capex by $1,446 per worker. No wonder Canadian GDP per capita - that is, standard of living - has actually dropped three per cent from 2010 levels, a lost decade that contrasts with the 35 per cent surge in U.S. GDP per capita in that period. Business-lobby whining about unfavourable Canadian tax and regulatory conditions is nonsensical. Even before Ottawa gave business a whopping additional tax break in accelerated depreciation on capital investments, Canada was already in the highest ranks of countries for ease of doing business. And offshore investors facing those same "unfavourable" Canadian conditions poured $65.8 billion into Canadian investments last year, close to the record set before the oil-price collapse. The stark reality is that Canadian business has less faith in Canada than outsiders. With the likely ebbing this year of global trade tensions that Canadian business also cites for lack of enterprise, we'll see this year if judicious caution or unwarranted trepidation is the real issue here.

David Olive is a Toronto-based business columnist for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @TheGrtRecession
